To compare facts or ideas, and perceive their relations and attributes, and thus distinguish truth from falsehood; to determine; to discern; to distinguish; to form an opinion about.
To determine upon or deliberation; to esteem; to think; to reckon.
To examine and pass sentence on; to try; to doom.
To exercise the functions of a magistrate over; to govern.
To hear and determine by authority, as a case before a court, or a controversy between two parties.
july: The seventh month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
june: One of the early discovered asteroids.
The sister and wife of Jupiter, the queen of heaven, and the goddess who presided over marriage. She corresponds to the Greek Hera.
The sixth month of the year, containing thirty days.
junior: Belonging to a younger person, or an earlier time of life.

Hence: One of a lower or later standing; specifically, in American colleges, one in the third year of his course, one in the fourth or final year being designated a senior; in some seminaries, one in the first year, in others, one in the second year, of a three years' course.
Less advanced in age than another; younger.
just: Precisely; exactly; -- in place, time, or degree; neither more nor less than is stated.
justice: The quality of being just; conformity to the principles of righteousness and rectitude in all things; strict performance of moral obligations; practical conformity to human or divine law; integrity in the dealings of men with each other; rectitude; equity; uprightness.
The rendering to every one his due or right; just treatment; requital of desert; merited reward or punishment; that which is due to one's conduct or motives.
keep: A cap for retaining anything, as a journal box, in place.
That which is kept in charge; a charge.
To attend upon; to have the care of; to tend.
To cause to remain in a given situation or condition; to maintain unchanged; to hold or preserve in any state or tenor.
To have habitually in stock for sale.
To have in custody; to have in some place for preservation; to take charge of.
To have in one's service; to have and maintain, as an assistant, a servant, a mistress, a horse, etc.
To hold; to restrain from departure or removal; not to let go of; to retain in one's power or possession; not to lose; to retain; to detain.
To last; to endure; to remain unimpaired.
To observe; to adhere to; to fulfill; not to swerve from or violate; to practice or perform, as duty; not to neglect; to be faithful to.
To preserve from danger, harm, or loss; to guard.
To preserve from discovery or publicity; not to communicate, reveal, or betray, as a secret.
To reside for a time; to lodge; to dwell.
To take care; to be solicitous; to watch.
key: A bar, pin or wedge, to secure a crank, pulley, coupling, etc., upon a shaft, and prevent relative turning; sometimes holding by friction alone, but more frequently by its resistance to shearing, being usually embedded partly in the shaft and partly in the crank, pulley, etc.
A piece of wood used as a wedge.
A wedge to unite two or more pieces, or adjust their relative position; a cotter; a forelock.
An instrument by means of which the bolt of a lock is shot or drawn; usually, a removable metal instrument fitted to the mechanism of a particular lock and operated by turning in its place.
Fig: The general pitch or tone of a sentence or utterance.
That part of a mechanism which serves to lock up, make fast, or adjust to position.
That part of the plastering which is forced through between the laths and holds the rest in place.
The last board of a floor when laid down.
khan: A king; a prince; a chief; a governor; -- so called among the Tartars, Turks, and Persians, and in countries now or formerly governed by them.
kill: To deprive of life, animal or vegetable, in any manner or by any means; to render inanimate; to put to death; to slay.
killing: Literally, that kills; having power to kill; fatal; in a colloquial sense, conquering; captivating; irresistible.
kind: Characteristic of the species; belonging to one's nature; natural; native.
Showing tenderness or goodness; disposed to do good and confer happiness; averse to hurting or paining; benevolent; benignant; gracious.
king: A Chinese musical instrument, consisting of resonant stones or metal plates, arranged according to their tones in a frame of wood, and struck with a hammer.
A chief ruler; a sovereign; one invested with supreme authority over a nation, country, or tribe, usually by hereditary succession; a monarch; a prince.
A crowned man in the game of draughts.
The chief piece in the game of chess.
The title of two historical books in the Old Testament.
kingdom: The rank, quality, state, or attributes of a king; royal authority; sovereign power; rule; dominion; monarchy.
The territory or country subject to a king or queen; the dominion of a monarch; the sphere in which one is king or has control.
know: To be assured; to feel confident.
knowledge: That which is gained and preserved by knowing; instruction; acquaintance; enlightenment; learning; scholarship; erudition.
That which is or may be known; the object of an act of knowing; a cognition; -- chiefly used in the plural.
The act or state of knowing; clear perception of fact, truth, or duty; certain apprehension; familiar cognizance; cognition.
la: Look; see; behold; -- sometimes followed by you.
The tone A; -- so called among the French and Italians.
label: A barrulet, or, rarely, a bendlet, with pendants, or points, usually three, especially used as a mark of cadency to distinguish an eldest or only son while his father is still living.
A brass rule with sights, formerly used, in connection with a circumferentor, to take altitudes.
A slip of ribbon, parchment, etc., attached to a document to hold the appended seal; also, the seal.
A tassel.
A writing annexed by way of addition, as a codicil added to a will.
In mediaeval art, the representation of a band or scroll containing an inscription.
The name now generally given to the projecting molding by the sides, and over the tops, of openings in mediaeval architecture. It always has a /quare form, as in the illustration.
labor: A measure of land in Mexico and Texas, equivalent to an area of 177/ acres.

Physical toil or bodily exertion, especially when fatiguing, irksome, or unavoidable, in distinction from sportive exercise; hard, muscular effort directed to some useful end, as agriculture, manufactures, and like; servile toil; exertion; work.
That which requires hard work for its accomplishment; that which demands effort.
The pitching or tossing of a vessel which results in the straining of timbers and rigging.
To be in travail; to suffer the pangs of childbirth.

To be oppressed with difficulties or disease; to do one's work under conditions which make it especially hard, wearisome; to move slowly, as against opposition, or under a burden; to be burdened; -- often with under, and formerly with of.
To exert muscular strength; to exert one's strength with painful effort, particularly in servile occupations; to work; to toil.
To exert one's powers of mind in the prosecution of any design; to strive; to take pains.
To form or fabricate with toil, exertion, or care.
To pitch or roll heavily, as a ship in a turbulent sea.
To work at; to work; to till; to cultivate by toil.
Travail; the pangs and efforts of childbirth.
lack: Blame; cause of blame; fault; crime; offense.
To be wanting; often, impersonally, with of, meaning, to be less than, short, not quite, etc.
To be without or destitute of; to want; to need.
To blame; to find fault with.
lady: A wife; -- not now in approved usage.
A woman having proprietary rights or authority; mistress; -- a feminine correlative of lord.
A woman of refined or gentle manners; a well-bred woman; -- the feminine correlative of gentleman.
A woman to whom the particular homage of a knight was paid; a woman to whom one is devoted or bound; a sweetheart.
A woman who looks after the domestic affairs of a family; a mistress; the female head of a household.
The day of the annunciation of the Virgin Mary, March 25. See Annunciation.
The triturating apparatus in the stomach of a lobster; -- so called from a fancied resemblance to a seated female figure. It consists of calcareous plates.
lake: A kind of fine white linen, formerly in use.
A large body of water contained in a depression of the earth's surface, and supplied from the drainage of a more or less extended area.
land: Any ground, soil, or earth whatsoever, as meadows, pastures, woods, etc., and everything annexed to it, whether by nature, as trees, water, etc., or by the hand of man, as buildings, fences, etc.; real estate.
Any portion, large or small, of the surface of the earth, considered by itself, or as belonging to an individual or a people, as a country, estate, farm, or tract.

In any surface prepared with indentations, perforations, or grooves, that part of the surface which is not so treated, as the level part of a millstone between the furrows, or the surface of the bore of a rifled gun between the grooves.
The ground left unplowed between furrows; any one of several portions into which a field is divided for convenience in plowing.
The inhabitants of a nation or people.
To go on shore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to come to the end of a course.
To set or put on shore from a ship or other water craft; to disembark; to debark.
landing: A going or bringing on shore.
The level part of a staircase, at the top of a flight of stairs, or connecting one flight with another.
language: A race, as distinguished by its speech.
Any means of conveying or communicating ideas; specifically, human speech; the expression of ideas by the voice; sounds, expressive of thought, articulated by the organs of the throat and mouth.
The characteristic mode of arranging words, peculiar to an individual speaker or writer; manner of expression; style.
The expression of ideas by writing, or any other instrumentality.
The forms of speech, or the methods of expressing ideas, peculiar to a particular nation.
The inarticulate sounds by which animals inferior to man express their feelings or their wants.
large: A musical note, formerly in use, equal to two longs, four breves, or eight semibreves.
Crossing the line of a ship's course in a favorable direction; -- said of the wind when it is abeam, or between the beam and the quarter.
Full in statement; diffuse; full; profuse.
Having more than usual power or capacity; having broad sympathies and generous impulses; comprehensive; -- said of the mind and heart.
Unrestrained by decorum; -- said of language.
last: A wooden block shaped like the human foot, on which boots and shoes are formed.
At a time next preceding the present time.
The burden of a ship; a cargo.
To continue in time; to endure; to remain in existence.
latin: A member of the Roman Catholic Church.
A native or inhabitant of Latium; a Roman.
The language of the ancient Romans.
launch: The boat of the largest size belonging to a ship of war; also, an open boat of any size driven by steam, naphtha, electricity, or the like.
The movement of a vessel from land into the water; especially, the sliding on ways from the stocks on which it is built.
To strike with, or as with, a lance; to pierce.
To throw, as a lance or dart; to hurl; to let fly.
law: An oath, as in the presence of a court.
An organic rule, as a constitution or charter, establishing and defining the conditions of the existence of a state or other organized community.
Any edict, decree, order, ordinance, statute, resolution, judicial, decision, usage, etc., or recognized, and enforced, by the controlling authority.
In general, a rule of being or of conduct, established by an authority able to enforce its will; a controlling regulation; the mode or order according to which an agent or a power acts.
In matematics: The rule according to which anything, as the change of value of a variable, or the value of the terms of a series, proceeds; mode or order of sequence.

In morals: The will of God as the rule for the disposition and conduct of all responsible beings toward him and toward each other; a rule of living, conformable to righteousness; the rule of action as obligatory on the conscience or moral nature.
Legal science; jurisprudence; the principles of equity; applied justice.
The Jewish or Mosaic code, and that part of Scripture where it is written, in distinction from the gospel; hence, also, the Old Testament.
lead: A thin strip of type metal, used to separate lines of type in printing.
An open way in an ice field.
The action of a tooth, as a tooth of a wheel, in impelling another tooth or a pallet.
The course of a rope from end to end.
The width of port opening which is uncovered by the valve, for the admission or release of steam, at the instant when the piston is at end of its stroke.

To guide or conduct one's self in, through, or along (a certain course); hence, to proceed in the way of; to follow the path or course of; to pass; to spend. Also, to cause (one) to proceed or follow in (a certain course).
the distance of haul, as from a cutting to an embankment.
leader: A block of hard wood pierced with suitable holes for leading ropes in their proper places.
A branch or small vein, not important in itself, but indicating the proximity of a better one.
A horse placed in advance of others; one of the forward pair of horses.
A net for leading fish into a pound, weir, etc. ; also, a line of gut, to which the snell of a fly hook is attached.
A performer who leads a band or choir in music; also, in an orchestra, the principal violinist; the one who plays at the head of the first violins.
A pipe for conducting rain water from a roof to a cistern or to the ground; a conductor.
A type having a dot or short row of dots upon its face.
One having authority to direct; a chief; a commander.
One who, or that which, leads or conducts; a guide; a conductor.
The first, or the principal, editorial article in a newspaper; a leading or main editorial article.
The principal wheel in any kind of machinery.
a row of dots, periods, or hyphens, used in tables of contents, etc., to lead the eye across a space to the right word or number.
leading: The act of guiding, directing, governing, or enticing; guidance.
league: An alliance or combination of two or more nations, parties, or persons, for the accomplishment of a purpose which requires a continued course of action, as for mutual defense, or for furtherance of commercial, religious, or political interests, etc.
leave: Liberty granted by which restraint or illegality is removed; permission; allowance; license.
To cease from; to desist from; to abstain from.
To desert; to abandon; to forsake; hence, to give up; to relinquish.
To have remaining at death; hence, to bequeath; as, he left a large estate; he left a good name; he left a legacy to his niece.
To let remain unremoved or undone; to let stay or continue, in distinction from what is removed or changed.
lee: That which settles at the bottom, as of a cask of liquor (esp. wine); sediment; dregs; -- used now only in the plural.
legal: According to the law of works, as distinguished from free grace; or resting on works for salvation.
According to the old or Mosaic dispensation; in accordance with the law of Moses.
let: A stroke in which a ball touches the top of the net in passing over.
To consider; to think; to esteem.
To leave; to relinquish; to abandon.
To permit; to allow; to suffer; -- either affirmatively, by positive act, or negatively, by neglecting to restrain or prevent.
To retard; to hinder; to impede; to oppose.
letter: A mark or character used as the representative of a sound, or of an articulation of the human organs of speech; a first element of written language.
A single type; type, collectively; a style of type.
A written or printed communication; a message expressed in intelligible characters on something adapted to conveyance, as paper, parchment, etc.; an epistle.
One who lets or permits; one who lets anything for hire.
Verbal expression; literal statement or meaning; exact signification or requirement.
level: A horizontal passage, drift, or adit, in a mine.
An instrument by which to find a horizontal line, or adjust something with reference to a horizontal line.
Even with anything else; of the same height; on the same line or plane; on the same footing; of equal importance; -- followed by with, sometimes by to.
Hence, figuratively, a certain position, rank, standard, degree, quality, character, etc., conceived of as in one of several planes of different elevation.
To aim a gun, spear, etc., horizontally; hence, to aim or point a weapon in direct line with the mark; fig., to direct the eye, mind, or effort, directly to an object.
To bring to a horizontal position, as a gun; hence, to point in taking aim; to aim; to direct.
liberal: Free to excess; regardless of law or moral restraint; licentious.
Not narrow or contracted in mind; not selfish; enlarged in spirit; catholic.
library: A building or apartment appropriated for holding such a collection of books.
lieutenant: A commissioned officer in the British navy, in rank next below a commander.
A commissioned officer in the army, next below a captain.
An officer who supplies the place of a superior in his absence; a representative of, or substitute for, another in the performance of any duty.
life: A person; a living being, usually a human being; as, many lives were sacrificed.
Enjoyment in the right use of the powers; especially, a spiritual existence; happiness in the favor of God; heavenly felicity.
Something dear to one as one's existence; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.

The potential principle, or force, by which the organs of animals and plants are started and continued in the performance of their several and cooperative functions; the vital force, whether regarded as physical or spiritual.

The state of being which begins with generation, birth, or germination, and ends with death; also, the time during which this state continues; that state of an animal or plant in which all or any of its organs are capable of performing all or any of their functions; -- used of all animal and vegetable organisms.
The system of animal nature; animals in general, or considered collectively.
light: Having little, or comparatively little, weight; not tending to the center of gravity with force; not heavy.
Indulging in, or inclined to, levity; wanting dignity or solemnity; trifling; gay; frivolous; airy; unsubstantial.
Not encumbered; unembarrassed; clear of impediments; hence, active; nimble; swift.
Not quite sound or normal; somewhat impaired or deranged; dizzy; giddy.
Open view; a visible state or condition; public observation; publicity.
That agent, force, or action in nature by the operation of which upon the organs of sight, objects are rendered visible or luminous.
The brightness of the eye or eyes.
The power of perception by vision.
To come by chance; to happen; -- with on or upon; formerly with into.
To come down suddenly and forcibly; to fall; -- with on or upon.
like: That which is equal or similar to another; the counterpart; an exact resemblance; a copy.
To be pleased with in a moderate degree; to approve; to take satisfaction in; to enjoy.
To have an appearance or expression; to look; to seem to be (in a specified condition).
To suit; to please; to be agreeable to.
likely: Such as suits; good-looking; pleasing; agreeable; handsome.
line: A circle of latitude or of longitude, as represented on a map.
A measure of length; one twelfth of an inch.
A number of shares taken by a jobber.
A row of letters, words, etc., written or printed; esp., a row of words extending across a page or column.
A row of men who are abreast of one another, whether side by side or some distance apart; -- opposed to column.
A threadlike crease marking the face or the hand; hence, characteristic mark.
A trench or rampart.
A verse, or the words which form a certain number of feet, according to the measure.
Course of conduct, thought, occupation, or policy; method of argument; department of industry, trade, or intellectual activity.
Dispositions made to cover extended positions, and presenting a front in but one direction to an enemy.
Instruction; doctrine.
One of the straight horizontal and parallel prolonged strokes on and between which the notes are placed.
That which has length, but not breadth or thickness.
The longer and finer fiber of flax.
The regular infantry of an army, as distinguished from militia, guards, volunteer corps, cavalry, artillery, etc.
The reins with which a horse is guided by his driver.
The track and roadbed of a railway; railroad.
The wire connecting one telegraphic station with another, or the whole of a system of telegraph wires under one management and name.
To impregnate; -- applied to brute animals.
To put something in the inside of; to fill; to supply, as a purse with money.
link: A bond of affinity, or a unit of valence between atoms; -- applied to a unit of chemical force or attraction.
A single ring or division of a chain.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like.
Any one of the several elementary pieces of a mechanism, as the fixed frame, or a rod, wheel, mass of confined liquid, etc., by which relative motion of other parts is produced and constrained.
Hence: Anything, whether material or not, which binds together, or connects, separate things; a part of a connected series; a tie; a bond.
The length of one joint of Gunter's chain, being the hundredth part of it, or 7.92 inches, the chain being 66 feet in length. Cf. Chain, n., 4.
list: A limit or boundary; a border.
A narrow strip of wood, esp. sapwood, cut from the edge of a plank or board.
A piece of woolen cloth with which the yarns are grasped by a workman.
A strip forming the woven border or selvedge of cloth, particularly of broadcloth, and serving to strengthen it; hence, a strip of cloth; a fillet.
A wirelike rim of tin left on an edge of the plate after it is coated.
The first thin coat of tin.
The lobe of the ear; the ear itself.
To desire or choose; to please.
To sew together, as strips of cloth, so as to make a show of colors, or form a border.
literature: Learning; acquaintance with letters or books.

The class of writings distinguished for beauty of style or expression, as poetry, essays, or history, in distinction from scientific treatises and works which contain positive knowledge; belles-lettres.
The occupation, profession, or business of doing literary work.
little: A small degree or scale; miniature.
In a small quantity or degree; not much; slightly; somewhat; -- often with a preceding it.
Small in dignity, power, or importance; not great; insignificant; contemptible.
Small in extent of views or sympathies; narrow; shallow; contracted; mean; illiberal; ungenerous.
live: To act habitually in conformity with; to practice.
To be or continue in existence; to exist; to remain; to be permanent; to last; -- said of inanimate objects, ideas, etc.
To enjoy or make the most of life; to be in a state of happiness.
To have a spiritual existence; to be quickened, nourished, and actuated by divine influence or faith.
To make one's abiding place or home; to abide; to dwell; to reside.
living: The benefice of a clergyman; an ecclesiastical charge which a minister receives.
The state of one who, or that which, lives; lives; life; existence.
local: A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a certain district.
On newspaper cant, an item of news relating to the place where the paper is published.
location: A contract for the use of a thing, or service of a person, for hire.
That which is located; a tract of land designated in place.
The act or process of locating.
The marking out of the boundaries, or identifying the place or site of, a piece of land, according to the description given in an entry, plan, map, etc.
long: A note formerly used in music, one half the length of a large, twice that of a breve.
By means of; by the fault of; because of.
Occurring or coming after an extended interval; distant in time; far away.
Through the whole extent or duration.
To feel a strong or morbid desire or craving; to wish for something with eagerness; -- followed by an infinitive, or by after or for.
look: In the imperative: see; behold; take notice; take care; observe; -- used to call attention.
To await the appearance of anything; to expect; to anticipate.

To direct the eyes for the purpose of seeing something; to direct the eyes toward an object; to observe with the eyes while keeping them directed; -- with various prepositions, often in a special or figurative sense. See Phrases below.
To have a particular direction or situation; to face; to front.
looking: The act of one who looks; a glance.
The manner in which one looks; appearance; countenance; face.
lord: A hump-backed person; -- so called sportively.
One who has power and authority; a master; a ruler; a governor; a prince; a proprietor, as of a manor.
losing: Given to flattery or deceit; flattering; cozening.
loss: Killed, wounded, and captured persons, or captured property.
The state of being lost or destroyed; especially, the wreck or foundering of a ship or other vessel.
The state of losing or having lost; the privation, defect, misfortune, harm, etc., which ensues from losing.
lot: That which happens without human design or forethought; chance; accident; hazard; fortune; fate.
The part, or fate, which falls to one, as it were, by chance, or without his planning.
love: A climbing species of Clematis (C. Vitalba).
Affection; kind feeling; friendship; strong liking or desire; fondness; good will; -- opposed to hate; often with of and an object.
Due gratitude and reverence to God.
Especially, devoted attachment to, or tender or passionate affection for, one of the opposite sex.
Nothing; no points scored on one side; -- used in counting score at tennis, etc.
The object of affection; -- often employed in endearing address.
To regard with passionate and devoted affection, as that of one sex for the other.
low: A hill; a mound; a grave.
The calling sound ordinarily made by cows and other bovine animals.
To make the calling sound of cows and other bovine animals; to moo.
lower: To be dark, gloomy, and threatening, as clouds; to be covered with dark and threatening clouds, as the sky; to show threatening signs of approach, as a tempest.
machine: A person who acts mechanically or at will of another.
A political organization arranged and controlled by one or more leaders for selfish, private or partisan ends.
Any mechanical contrivance, as the wooden horse with which the Greeks entered Troy; a coach; a bicycle.
Supernatural agency in a poem, or a superhuman being introduced to perform some exploit.
magazine: A chamber in a gun for holding a number of cartridges to be fed automatically to the piece.
A pamphlet published periodically containing miscellaneous papers or compositions.
A receptacle in which anything is stored, especially military stores, as ammunition, arms, provisions, etc.
The building or room in which the supply of powder is kept in a fortification or a ship.
main: A hand or match at dice.
A stake played for at dice.
Principal; chief; first in size, rank, importance, etc.
The great sea, as distinguished from an arm, bay, etc. ; the high sea; the ocean.
The largest throw in a match at dice; a throw at dice within given limits, as in the game of hazard.
mainly: Very strongly; mightily; to a great degree.
major: An officer next in rank above a captain and next below a lieutenant colonel; the lowest field officer.
Greater by a semitone, either in interval or in difference of pitch from another tone.
majority: The condition of being of full age, or authorized by law to manage one's own affairs.
The military rank of a major.
The quality or condition of being major or greater; superiority.
make: A companion; a mate; often, a husband or a wife.
Structure, texture, constitution of parts; construction; shape; form.
To be engaged or concerned in.
To cause to appear to be; to constitute subjectively; to esteem, suppose, or represent.
To cause to exist; to bring into being; to form; to produce; to frame; to fashion; to create.
To compose verses; to write poetry; to versify.
To compose, as parts, ingredients, or materials; to constitute; to form; to amount to.
To form of materials; to cause to exist in a certain form; to construct; to fabricate.
To increase; to augment; to accrue.
To proceed; to tend; to move; to go; as, he made toward home; the tiger made at the sportsmen.
To put a desired or desirable condition; to cause to thrive.
To reach; to attain; to arrive at or in sight of.
To require; to constrain; to compel; to force; to cause; to occasion; -- followed by a noun or pronoun and infinitive.
male: A plant bearing only staminate flowers.
Capable of producing fertilization, but not of bearing fruit; -- said of stamens and antheridia, and of the plants, or parts of plants, which bear them.
man: An adult male servant; also, a vassal; a subject.
One of the piece with which certain games, as chess or draughts, are played.
To furnish with strength for action; to prepare for efficiency; to fortify.
management: Judicious use of means to accomplish an end; conduct directed by art or address; skillful treatment; cunning practice; -- often in a bad sense.
The collective body of those who manage or direct any enterprise or interest; the board of managers.
manager: A person who conducts business or household affairs with economy and frugality; a good economist.
many: A retinue of servants; a household.
Consisting of a great number; numerous; not few.
The populace; the common people; the majority of people, or of a community.
march: A territorial border or frontier; a region adjacent to a boundary line; a confine; -- used chiefly in the plural, and in English history applied especially to the border land on the frontiers between England and Scotland, and England and Wales.
Hence: Measured and regular advance or movement, like that of soldiers moving in order; stately or deliberate walk; steady onward movement.

TO cause to move with regular steps in the manner of a soldier; to cause to move in military array, or in a body, as troops; to cause to advance in a steady, regular, or stately manner; to cause to go by peremptory command, or by force.
The third month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
To border; to be contiguous; to lie side by side.
To move with regular steps, as a soldier; to walk in a grave, deliberate, or stately manner; to advance steadily.
marine: A solider serving on shipboard; a sea soldier; one of a body of troops trained to do duty in the navy.
mark: A character (usually a cross) made as a substitute for a signature by one who can not write.
A characteristic or essential attribute; a differential.
A license of reprisals. See Marque.

A visible sign or impression made or left upon anything; esp., a line, point, stamp, figure, or the like, drawn or impressed, so as to attract the attention and convey some information or intimation; a token; a trace.
An evidence of presence, agency, or influence; a significative token; a symptom; a trace; specifically, a permanent impression of one's activity or character.
An old weight and coin. See Marc.
Badge or sign of honor, rank, or official station.
Image; likeness; hence, those formed in one's image; children; descendants.
That toward which a missile is directed; a thing aimed at; what one seeks to hit or reach.
The unit of monetary account of the German Empire, equal to 23.8 cents of United States money; the equivalent of one hundred pfennigs. Also, a silver coin of this value.
marriage: The act of marrying, or the state of being married; legal union of a man and a woman for life, as husband and wife; wedlock; matrimony.
martin: A perforated stone-faced runner for grinding.
One of several species of swallows, usually having the tail less deeply forked than the tail of the common swallows.
mass: The principal part; the main body.
The quantity of matter which a body contains, irrespective of its bulk or volume.
The sacrifice in the sacrament of the Eucharist, or the consecration and oblation of the host.
master: A male person having another living being so far subject to his will, that he can, in the main, control his or its actions; -- formerly used with much more extensive application than now. (a) The employer of a servant. (b) The owner of a slave. (c) The person to whom an apprentice is articled. (d) A sovereign, prince, or feudal noble; a chief, or one exercising similar authority. (e) The head of a household. (f) The male head of a school or college. (g) A male teacher. (h) The director of a number of persons performing a ceremony or sharing a feast. (i) The owner of a docile brute, -- especially a dog or horse. (j) The controller of a familiar spirit or other supernatural being.
A person holding an office of authority among the Freemasons, esp. the presiding officer; also, a person holding a similar office in other civic societies.
A title given by courtesy, now commonly pronounced mister, except when given to boys; -- sometimes written Mister, but usually abbreviated to Mr.
A young gentleman; a lad, or small boy.

The commander of a merchant vessel; -- usually called captain. Also, a commissioned officer in the navy ranking next above ensign and below lieutenant; formerly, an officer on a man-of-war who had immediate charge, under the commander, of sailing the vessel.
match: A bringing together of two parties suited to one another, as for a union, a trial of skill or force, a contest, or the like
A candidate for matrimony; one to be gained in marriage.
A contest to try strength or skill, or to determine superiority; an emulous struggle.
A perforated board, block of plaster, hardened sand, etc., in which a pattern is partly imbedded when a mold is made, for giving shape to the surfaces of separation between the parts of the mold.
A person or thing equal or similar to another; one able to mate or cope with another; an equal; a mate.

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire, made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burning some time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood dipped at one end in a substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparation of phosphorus or chlorate of potassium.
Equality of conditions in contest or competition.
To be united in marriage; to mate.
To make equal, proportionate, or suitable; to adapt, fit, or suit (one thing to another).
To marry; to give in marriage.
To oppose as equal; to contend successfully against.
material: Hence: Pertaining to, or affecting, the physical nature of man, as distinguished from the mental or moral nature; relating to the bodily wants, interests, and comforts.
Pertaining to the matter, as opposed to the form, of a thing. See Matter.
The substance or matter of which anything is made or may be made.
mathematics: That science, or class of sciences, which treats of the exact relations existing between quantities or magnitudes, and of the methods by which, in accordance with these relations, quantities sought are deducible from other quantities known or supposed; the science of spatial and quantitative relations.
matter: Amount; quantity; portion; space; -- often indefinite.
Inducing cause or occasion, especially of anything disagreeable or distressing; difficulty; trouble.
Substance excreted from living animal bodies; that which is thrown out or discharged in a tumor, boil, or abscess; pus; purulent substance.

That of which anything is composed; constituent substance; material; the material or substantial part of anything; the constituent elements of conception; that into which a notion may be analyzed; the essence; the pith; the embodiment.
That of which the sensible universe and all existent bodies are composed; anything which has extension, occupies space, or is perceptible by the senses; body; substance.
That which is permanent, or is supposed to be given, and in or upon which changes are effected by psychological or physical processes and relations; -- opposed to form.
That which one has to treat, or with which one has to do; concern; affair; business.

That with regard to, or about which, anything takes place or is done; the thing aimed at, treated of, or treated; subject of action, discussion, consideration, feeling, complaint, legal action, or the like; theme.
To be of importance; to import; to signify.
To regard as important; to take account of; to care for.
Written manuscript, or anything to be set in type; copy; also, type set up and ready to be used, or which has been used, in printing.
maximum: The greatest quantity or value attainable in a given case; or, the greatest value attained by a quantity which first increases and then begins to decrease; the highest point or degree; -- opposed to minimum.
may: An auxiliary verb qualifyng the meaning of another verb, by expressing: (a) Ability, competency, or possibility; -- now oftener expressed by can.
The early part or springtime of life.
The fifth month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
The flowers of the hawthorn; -- so called from their time of blossoming; also, the hawthorn.
mayor: The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief officer of a municipal corporation. In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge.
meanwhile: In the intervening time; during the interval.
The intervening time; as, in the meantime (or mean time).
medal: A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device, and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or an illustrious person, or to serve as a reward.
medicine: Any substance administered in the treatment of disease; a remedial agent; a remedy; physic.
The science which relates to the prevention, cure, or alleviation of disease.
meet: Suitable; fit; proper; appropriate; qualified; convenient.
To come in collision with; to confront in conflict; to encounter hostilely; as, they met the enemy and defeated them; the ship met opposing winds and currents.
To come together by mutual concessions; hence, to agree; to harmonize; to unite.
To come together with hostile purpose; to have an encounter or conflict.

To join, or come in contact with; esp., to come in contact with by approach from an opposite direction; to come upon or against, front to front, as distinguished from contact by following and overtaking.
To perceive; to come to a knowledge of; to have personal acquaintance with; to experience; to suffer; as, the eye met a horrid sight; he met his fate.
member: A part of a discourse or of a period or sentence; a clause; a part of a verse.
A part of an animal capable of performing a distinct office; an organ; a limb.
Any essential part, as a post, tie rod, strut, etc., of a framed structure, as a bridge truss.
Any part of a building, whether constructional, as a pier, column, lintel, or the like, or decorative, as a molding, or group of moldings.
Either of the two parts of an algebraic equation, connected by the sign of equality.
Hence, a part of a whole; an independent constituent of a body
membership: The collective body of members, as of a society.
The state of being a member.
memorial: A species of informal state paper, much used in negotiation.
A written representation of facts, addressed to the government, or to some branch of it, or to a society, etc., -- often accompanied with a petition.
Anything intended to preserve the memory of a person or event; something which serves to keep something else in remembrance; a monument.
memory: The faculty of the mind by which it retains the knowledge of previous thoughts, impressions, or events.
men: A man; one; -- used with a verb in the singular, and corresponding to the present indefinite one or they.
metal: A mine from which ores are taken.
Glass in a state of fusion.
The broken stone used in macadamizing roads and ballasting railroads.
The effective power or caliber of guns carried by a vessel of war.
The substance of which anything is made; material; hence, constitutional disposition; character; temper.
method: Orderly arrangement, elucidation, development, or classification; clear and lucid exhibition; systematic arrangement peculiar to an individual.
metropolitan: A bishop whose see is civil metropolis. His rank is intermediate between that of an archbishop and a patriarch.
The superior or presiding bishop of a country or province.
mexican: A native or inhabitant of Mexico.
middle: The point or part equally distant from the extremities or exterior limits, as of a line, a surface, or a solid; an intervening point or part in space, time, or order of series; the midst; central portion
might: Force or power of any kind, whether of body or mind; energy or intensity of purpose, feeling, or action; means or resources to effect an object; strength; force; power; ability; capacity.
mile: A certain measure of distance, being equivalent in England and the United States to 320 poles or rods, or 5,280 feet.
military: The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; the army.
mill: A hardened steel roller having a design in relief, used for imprinting a reversed copy of the design in a softer metal, as copper.
A money of account of the United States, having the value of the tenth of a cent, or the thousandth of a dollar.
A passage underground through which ore is shot.
An excavation in rock, transverse to the workings, from which material for filling is obtained.
To make a raised border around the edges of, or to cut fine grooves or indentations across the edges of, as of a coin, or a screw head; also, to stamp in a coining press; to coin.
To roll into bars, as steel.
To shape, finish, or transform by passing through a machine; specifically, to shape or dress, as metal, by means of a rotary cutter.
To swim under water; -- said of air-breathing creatures.
miller: One who keeps or attends a flour mill or gristmill.
million: A very great number; an indefinitely large number.
The mass of common people; -- with the article the.
The number of ten hundred thousand, or a thousand thousand, -- written 1,000, 000. See the Note under Hundred.
mind: The intellectual or rational faculty in man; the understanding; the intellect; the power that conceives, judges, or reasons; also, the entire spiritual nature; the soul; -- often in distinction from the body.
The state, at any given time, of the faculties of thinking, willing, choosing, and the like; psychical activity or state; as: (a) Opinion; judgment; belief.
mine: A cavity or tunnel made under a fortification or other work, for the purpose of blowing up the superstructure with some explosive agent.
Fig.: A rich source of wealth or other good.
To dig into, for ore or metal.
To form subterraneous tunnel or hole; to form a burrow or lodge in the earth; as, the mining cony.
To get, as metals, out of the earth by digging.
mining: The act or business of making mines or of working them.
minister: A representative of a government, sent to the court, or seat of government, of a foreign nation to transact diplomatic business.
A servant; a subordinate; an officer or assistant of inferior rank; hence, an agent, an instrument.
One to whom the sovereign or executive head of a government intrusts the management of affairs of state, or some department of such affairs.
To act as a servant, attendant, or agent; to attend and serve; to perform service in any office, sacred or secular.
To supply or to things needful; esp., to supply consolation or remedies.
ministry: The act of ministering; ministration; service.
The body of ministers of state; also, the clergy, as a body.
The office, duties, or functions of a minister, servant, or agent; ecclesiastical, executive, or ambassadorial function or profession.
minor: A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.
minute: A fixed part of a module. See Module.
A nautical or a geographic mile.
A point of time; a moment.
A very small part of anything, or anything very small; a jot; a tittle.
The sixtieth part of a degree; sixty seconds (Marked thus ('); as, 10¡ 20').
The sixtieth part of an hour; sixty seconds. (Abbrev. m.; as, 4 h. 30 m.)
Very small; little; tiny; fine; slight; slender; inconsiderable.
miss: A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a girl or a woman who has not been married. See Mistress, 5.
In the game of three-card loo, an extra hand, dealt on the table, which may be substituted for the hand dealt to a player.
To be absent, deficient, or wanting.
To fail to hit; to fly wide; to deviate from the true direction.
To fail to obtain, learn, or find; -- with of.
To omit; to fail to have or to do; to get without; to dispense with; -- now seldom applied to persons.
mission: A course of extraordinary sermons and services at a particular place and time for the special purpose of quickening the faith and zeal participants, and of converting unbelievers.
An organization for worship and work, dependent on one or more churches.
Persons sent; any number of persons appointed to perform any service; a delegation; an embassy.
mixed: Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix, v. t. & i.
mobile: Capable of being moved, aroused, or excited; capable of spontaneous movement.
Capable of being moved; not fixed in place or condition; movable.
Easily moved in feeling, purpose, or direction; excitable; changeable; fickle.
model: A miniature representation of a thing, with the several parts in due proportion; sometimes, a facsimile of the same size.
A person who poses as a pattern to an artist.
Any copy, or resemblance, more or less exact.
That by which a thing is to be measured; standard.
money: A piece of metal, as gold, silver, copper, etc., coined, or stamped, and issued by the sovereign authority as a medium of exchange in financial transactions between citizens and with government; also, any number of such pieces; coin.
more: A greater quantity, amount, or number; that which exceeds or surpasses in any way what it is compared with.
Greater in number; exceeding in numbers; -- with the plural.
Greater in quality, amount, degree, quality, and the like; with the singular.
In a greater quantity; in or to a greater extent or degree.
That which is in addition; something other and further; an additional or greater amount.
most: Consisting of the greatest number or quantity; greater in number or quantity than all the rest; nearly all.
In the greatest or highest degree.
mostly: For the greatest part; for the most part; chiefly; in the main.
mother: A female parent; especially, one of the human race; a woman who has borne a child.

A film or membrane which is developed on the surface of fermented alcoholic liquids, such as vinegar, wine, etc., and acts as a means of conveying the oxygen of the air to the alcohol and other combustible principles of the liquid, thus leading to their oxidation.
That which has produced or nurtured anything; source of birth or origin; generatrix.
The female superior or head of a religious house, as an abbess, etc.
motion: An application made to a court or judge orally in open court. Its object is to obtain an order or rule directing some act to be done in favor of the applicant.
Change in the relative position of the parts of anything; action of a machine with respect to the relative movement of its parts.
Change of pitch in successive sounds, whether in the same part or in groups of parts.
Movement of the mind, desires, or passions; mental act, or impulse to any action; internal activity.
The act, process, or state of changing place or position; movement; the passing of a body from one place or position to another, whether voluntary or involuntary; -- opposed to rest.
To make proposal; to offer plans.
motor: A prime mover; a machine by means of which a source of power, as steam, moving water, electricity, etc., is made available for doing mechanical work.
One who, or that which, imparts motion; a source of mechanical power.
mount: A bulwark for offense or defense; a mound.

Hence: To put upon anything that sustains and fits for use, as a gun on a carriage, a map or picture on cloth or paper; to prepare for being worn or otherwise used, as a diamond by setting, or a sword blade by adding the hilt, scabbard, etc.
To get up on anything, as a platform or scaffold; especially, to seat one's self on a horse for riding.
To get upon; to ascend; to climb.
To place one's self on, as a horse or other animal, or anything that one sits upon; to bestride.
To raise aloft; to lift on high.
To rise on high; to go up; to be upraised or uplifted; to tower aloft; to ascend; -- often with up.
mountain: A large mass of earth and rock, rising above the common level of the earth or adjacent land; earth and rock forming an isolated peak or a ridge; an eminence higher than a hill; a mount.
move: An act for the attainment of an object; a step in the execution of a plan or purpose.
The act of moving one of the pieces, from one position to another, in the progress of the game.
To apply to, as for aid.
To arouse the feelings or passions of; especially, to excite to tenderness or compassion; to touch pathetically; to excite, as an emotion.
To change the place of a piece in accordance with the rules of the game.
To excite to action by the presentation of motives; to rouse by representation, persuasion, or appeal; to influence.
movement: A system of mechanism for transmitting motion of a definite character, or for transforming motion; as, the wheelwork of a watch.
Motion of the mind or feelings; emotion.
The rhythmical progression, pace, and tempo of a piece.
moving: The act of changing place or posture; esp., the act of changing one's dwelling place or place of business.
much: A thing uncommon, wonderful, or noticeable; something considerable.
To a great degree or extent; greatly; abundantly; far; nearly.
multiple: A quantity containing another quantity a number of times without a remainder.
Containing more than once, or more than one; consisting of more than one; manifold; repeated many times; having several, or many, parts.
municipality: A municipal district; a borough, city, or incorporated town or village.
murder: The offense of killing a human being with malice prepense or aforethought, express or implied; intentional and unlawful homicide.
To destroy; to put an end to.
museum: A repository or a collection of natural, scientific, or literary curiosities, or of works of art.
music: Harmony; an accordant combination of simultaneous tones.
Melody; a rhythmical and otherwise agreeable succession of tones.
musician: One skilled in the art or science of music; esp., a skilled singer, or performer on a musical instrument.
must: The expressed juice of the grape, or other fruit, before fermentation.
name: A descriptive or qualifying appellation given to a person or thing, on account of a character or acts.
A person, an individual.
Reputed character; reputation, good or bad; estimation; fame; especially, illustrious character or fame; honorable estimation; distinction.
The title by which any person or thing is known or designated; a distinctive specific appellation, whether of an individual or a class.
nation: A part, or division, of the people of the earth, distinguished from the rest by common descent, language, or institutions; a race; a stock.
One of the divisions of university students in a classification according to nativity, formerly common in Europe.
One of the four divisions (named from the parts of Scotland) in which students were classified according to their nativity.
The body of inhabitants of a country, united under an independent government of their own.
national: Attached to one's own country or nation.
native: Any of the live stock found in a region, as distinguished from such as belong to pure and distinct imported breeds.
Arising by birth; having an origin; born.
natural: A character [/] used to contradict, or to remove the effect of, a sharp or flat which has preceded it, and to restore the unaltered note.
Applied to an air or modulation of harmony which moves by easy and smooth transitions, digressing but little from the original key.
Connected by the ties of consanguinity.
One born without the usual powers of reason or understanding; an idiot.
nature: Conformity to that which is natural, as distinguished from that which is artifical, or forced, or remote from actual experience.
Constitution or quality of mind or character.
Physical constitution or existence; the vital powers; the natural life.
The established or regular course of things; usual order of events; connection of cause and effect.
The existing system of things; the world of matter, or of matter and mind; the creation; the universe.

The personified sum and order of causes and effects; the powers which produce existing phenomena, whether in the total or in detail; the agencies which carry on the processes of creation or of being; -- often conceived of as a single and separate entity, embodying the total of all finite agencies and forces as disconnected from a creating or ordering intelligence.

The sum of qualities and attributes which make a person or thing what it is, as distinct from others; native character; inherent or essential qualities or attributes; peculiar constitution or quality of being.
navy: A fleet of ships; an assemblage of merchantmen, or so many as sail in company.
near: At a little distance, in place, time, manner, or degree; not remote; nigh.
Not far distant in time, place, or degree; not remote; close at hand; adjacent; neighboring; nigh.
nearly: In a near manner; not remotely; closely; intimately; almost.
necessary: Impossible to be otherwise, or to be dispensed with, without preventing the attainment of a desired result; indispensable; requiste; essential.
Such as must be; impossible to be otherwise; not to be avoided; inevitable.
Such things, in respect to infants, lunatics, and married women, as are requisite for support suitable to station.
need: A state that requires supply or relief; pressing occasion for something; necessity; urgent want.
To be in want of; to have cause or occasion for; to lack; to require, as supply or relief.
To be wanted; to be necessary.
Want of the means of subsistence; poverty; indigence; destitution.
negative: A picture upon glass or other material, in which the light portions of the original are represented in some opaque material (usually reduced silver), and the dark portions by the uncovered and transparent or semitransparent ground of the picture.
A word used in denial or refusal; as, not, no.
The refusal or withholding of assents; veto.
To neutralize the force of; to counteract.
To prove unreal or intrue; to disprove.
neighborhood: The disposition becoming a neighbor; neighborly kindness or good will.
The inhabitants who live in the vicinity of each other; as, the fire alarmed all the neiborhood.
The quality or condition of being a neighbor; the state of being or dwelling near; proximity.
network: A fabric of threads, cords, or wires crossing each other at certain intervals, and knotted or secured at the crossings, thus leaving spaces or meshes between them.
never: In no degree; not in the least; not.
Not ever; not at any time; at no time, whether past, present, or future.
new: Not of ancient extraction, or of a family of ancient descent; not previously kniwn or famous.
news: A report of recent occurences; information of something that has lately taken place, or of something before unknown; fresh tindings; recent intelligence.
newspaper: A sheet of paper printed and distributed, at stated intervals, for conveying intelligence of passing events, advocating opinions, etc.; a public print that circulates news, advertisements, proceedings of legislative bodies, public announcements, etc.
next: Adjoining in a series; immediately preceding or following in order.
Nearest in place; having no similar object intervening.
night: A lifeless or unenlivened period, as when nature seems to sleep.

That part of the natural day when the sun is beneath the horizon, or the time from sunset to sunrise; esp., the time between dusk and dawn, when there is no light of the sun, but only moonlight, starlight, or artificial light.
The period after the close of life; death.
normal: A straight line or plane drawn from any point of a curve or surface so as to be perpendicular to the curve or surface at that point.
Denoting a solution of such strength that every cubic centimeter contains the same number of milligrams of the element in question as the number of its molecular weight.
north: That one of the four cardinal points of the compass, at any place, which lies in the direction of the true meridian, and to the left hand of a person facing the east; the direction opposite to the south.
norwegian: That branch of the Scandinavian language spoken in Norway.
not: A word used to express negation, prohibition, denial, or refusal.
notable: A person, or thing, of distinction.
Capable of being noted; noticeable; plan; evident.
One of a number of persons, before the revolution of 1789, chiefly of the higher orders, appointed by the king to constitute a representative body.
note: A brief remark; a marginal comment or explanation; hence, an annotation on a text or author; a comment; a critical, explanatory, or illustrative observation.
A brief writing intended to assist the memory; a memorandum; a minute.
A character, variously formed, to indicate the length of a tone, and variously placed upon the staff to indicate its pitch. Hence:
A diplomatic missive or written communication.
A key of the piano or organ.
A list of items or of charges; an account.
A mark or token by which a thing may be known; a visible sign; a character; a distinctive mark or feature; a characteristic quality.
A mark, or sign, made to call attention, to point out something to notice, or the like; a sign, or token, proving or giving evidence.
A musical sound; a tone; an utterance; a tune.
A short informal letter; a billet.
Know not; knows not.
Need; needful business.
Notification; information; intelligence.
Nut.
Observation; notice; heed.
State of being under observation.
Stigma; brand; reproach.
To annotate.
To butt; to push with the horns.
To charge, as with crime (with of or for before the thing charged); to brand.
To notice with care; to observe; to remark; to heed; to attend to.
To record in writing; to make a memorandum of.
To set down in musical characters.
nothing: A thing of no account, value, or note; something irrelevant and impertinent; something of comparative unimportance; utter insignificance; a trifle.
In no degree; not at all; in no wise.
Not anything; no thing (in the widest sense of the word thing); -- opposed to anything and something.
novel: A fictitious tale or narrative, professing to be conformed to real life; esp., one intended to exhibit the operation of the passions, and particularly of love.
november: The eleventh month of the year, containing thirty days.
now: At a time contemporaneous with something spoken of or contemplated; at a particular time referred to.
Existing at the present time; present.
In present circumstances; things being as they are; -- hence, used as a connective particle, to introduce an inference or an explanation.
The present time or moment; the present.
number: A collection of many individuals; a numerous assemblage; a multitude; many.
Quantity, regarded as made up of an aggregate of separate things.
That which admits of being counted or reckoned; a unit, or an aggregate of units; a numerable aggregate or collection of individuals; an assemblage made up of distinct things expressible by figures.
The measure of the relation between quantities or things of the same kind; that abstract species of quantity which is capable of being expressed by figures; numerical value.
The state or quality of being numerable or countable.
To count; to reckon; to ascertain the units of; to enumerate.
To reckon as one of a collection or multitude.
numbers: pl. of Number. The fourth book of the Pentateuch, containing the census of the Hebrews.
numerous: Consisting of poetic numbers; rhythmical; measured and counted; melodious; musical.
occur: To go in order to meet; to make reply.
To meet or come to the mind; to suggest itself; to be presented to the imagination or memory.
ocean: The whole body of salt water which covers more than three fifths of the surface of the globe; -- called also the sea, or great sea.
october: Ale or cider made in that month.
The tenth month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
of: Denoting passage from one state to another; from.
Denoting the agent, or person by whom, or thing by which, anything is, or is done; by.
off: Away; begone; -- a command to depart.
In a general sense, denoting from or away from; as:
The side of the field that is on the right of the wicket keeper.
offensive: The state or posture of one who offends or makes attack; aggressive attitude; the act of the attacking party; -- opposed to defensive.
offer: To make an attempt; to make an essay or a trial; -- used with at.
To present itself; to be at hand.
To present, as an act of worship; to immolate; to sacrifice; to present in prayer or devotion; -- often with up.
office: Any service other than that of ordination and the Mass; any prescribed religious service.
That which is performed, intended, or assigned to be done, by a particular thing, or that which anything is fitted to perform; a function; -- answering to duty in intelligent beings.
The apartments or outhouses in which the domestics discharge the duties attached to the service of a house, as kitchens, pantries, stables, etc.
official: An ecclesiastical judge appointed by a bishop, chapter, archdeacon, etc., with charge of the spiritual jurisdiction.
One who holds an office; esp., a subordinate executive officer or attendant.
old: Aged; antiquated; hence, wanting in the mental vigor or other qualities belonging to youth; -- used disparagingly as a term of reproach.
Used colloquially as a term of cordiality and familiarity.
on: At the peril of, or for the safety of.
Attached to the body, as clothing or ornament, or for use.
once: At some one period of time; -- used indefinitely.
By limitation to the number one; for one time; not twice nor any number of times more than one.
one: A symbol representing a unit, as 1, or i.
Being a single unit, or entire being or thing, and no more; not multifold; single; individual.
Closely bound together; undivided; united; constituting a whole.
Pointing out a contrast, or denoting a particular thing or person different from some other specified; -- used as a correlative adjective, with or without the.
Single in kind; the same; a common.
only: Hence, figuratively: Alone, by reason of superiority; preeminent; chief.
In one manner or degree; for one purpose alone; simply; merely; barely.
Save or except (that); -- an adversative used elliptically with or without that, and properly introducing a single fact or consideration.
So and no otherwise; no other than; exclusively; solely; wholly.
onto: On the top of; upon; on. See On to, under On, prep.
open: Not closed or stopped with the finger; -- said of the string of an instrument, as of a violin, when it is allowed to vibrate throughout its whole length.
To bark on scent or view of the game.
To disclose; to reveal; to interpret; to explain.
To make known; to discover; also, to render available or accessible for settlements, trade, etc.
To unclose; to form a hole, breach, or gap; to be unclosed; to be parted.
Uttered, as a consonant, with the oral passage simply narrowed without closure, as in uttering s.

Without reserve or false pretense; sincere; characterized by sincerity; unfeigned; frank; also, generous; liberal; bounteous; -- applied to personal appearance, or character, and to the expression of thought and feeling, etc.
opening: A place which is open; a breach; an aperture; a gap; cleft, or hole.
opera: A drama, either tragic or comic, of which music forms an essential part; a drama wholly or mostly sung, consisting of recitative, arials, choruses, duets, trios, etc., with orchestral accompaniment, preludes, and interludes, together with appropriate costumes, scenery, and action; a lyric drama.
The score of a musical drama, either written or in print; a play set to music.
operate: To act or produce effect on the mind; to exert moral power or influence.
To deal in stocks or any commodity with a view to speculative profits.
To perform a work or labor; to exert power or strengh, physical or mechanical; to act.
To perform some manual act upon a human body in a methodical manner, and usually with instruments, with a view to restore soundness or health, as in amputation, lithotomy, etc.
To produce an appropriate physical effect; to issue in the result designed by nature; especially (Med.), to take appropriate effect on the human system.
To produce, as an effect; to cause.
operation: Any methodical action of the hand, or of the hand with instruments, on the human body, to produce a curative or remedial effect, as in amputation, etc.
Something to be done; some transformation to be made upon quantities, the transformation being indicated either by rules or symbols.
The act or process of operating; agency; the exertion of power, physical, mechanical, or moral.
The method of working; mode of action.
opportunity: Fit or convenient time; a time or place favorable for executing a purpose; a suitable combination of conditions; suitable occasion; chance.
opposite: Extremely different; inconsistent; contrary; repugnant; antagonistic.
One who opposes; an opponent; an antagonist.
Placed directly in front of another part or organ, as a stamen which stands before a petal.
Set over against each other, but separated by the whole diameter of the stem, as two leaves at the same node.
opposition: Repugnance; contrariety of sentiment, interest, or purpose; antipathy.
That which opposes; an obstacle; specifically, the aggregate of persons or things opposing; hence, in politics and parliamentary practice, the party opposed to the party in power.
The act of opposing; an attempt to check, restrain, or defeat; resistance.

The relation between two propositions when, having the same subject and predicate, they differ in quantity, or in quality, or in both; or between two propositions which have the same matter but a different form.
The state of being placed over against; situation so as to front something else.
orange: The fruit of a tree of the genus Citrus (C. Aurantium). It is usually round, and consists of pulpy carpels, commonly ten in number, inclosed in a leathery rind, which is easily separable, and is reddish yellow when ripe.
orchestra: A band composed, for the largest part, of players of the various viol instruments, many of each kind, together with a proper complement of wind instruments of wood and brass; -- as distinguished from a military or street band of players on wind instruments, and from an assemblage of solo players for the rendering of concerted pieces, such as septets, octets, and the like.
Loosely: A band of instrumental musicians performing in a theater, concert hall, or other place of public amusement.

Strictly: A band suitable for the performance of symphonies, overtures, etc., as well as for the accompaniment of operas, oratorios, cantatas, masses, and the like, or of vocal and instrumental solos.
The place in any public hall appropriated to a band of instrumental musicians.

The space in a theater between the stage and the audience; -- originally appropriated by the Greeks to the chorus and its evolutions, afterward by the Romans to persons of distinction, and by the moderns to a band of instrumental musicians.
order: A command; a mandate; a precept; a direction.
Regular arrangement; any methodical or established succession or harmonious relation; method; system
The customary mode of procedure; established system, as in the conduct of debates or the transaction of business; usage; custom; fashion.

The disposition of a column and its component parts, and of the entablature resting upon it, in classical architecture; hence (as the column and entablature are the characteristic features of classical architecture) a style or manner of architectural designing.
The placing of words and members in a sentence in such a manner as to contribute to force and beauty or clearness of expression.
organization: That which is organized; an organized existence; an organism
The state of being organized; also, the relations included in such a state or condition.
an arrangement of parts for the performance of the functions necessary to life.
origin: That from which anything primarily proceeds; the fountain; the spring; the cause; the occasion.
The first existence or beginning of anything; the birth.
The point of attachment or end of a muscle which is fixed during contraction; -- in contradistinction to insertion.
originally: In the original time, or in an original manner; primarily; from the beginning or origin; not by derivation, or imitation.
other: Different from that which, or the one who, has been specified; not the same; not identical; additional; second of two.
out: A word or words omitted by the compositor in setting up copy; an omission.

Beyond the bounds of what is true, reasonable, correct, proper, common, etc.; in error or mistake; in a wrong or incorrect position or opinion; in a state of disagreement, opposition, etc.; in an inharmonious relation.
Not in the position to score in playing a game; not in the state or turn of the play for counting or gaining scores.
outside: The external part of a thing; the part, end, or side which forms the surface; that which appears, or is manifest; that which is superficial; the exterior.
The part or space which lies without an inclosure; the outer side, as of a door, walk, or boundary.
over: A certain number of balls (usually four) delivered successively from behind one wicket, after which the ball is bowled from behind the other wicket as many times, the fielders changing places.
At an end; beyond the limit of continuance; completed; finished.
From inside to outside, above or across the brim.
owner: One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal or rightful title, whether he is the possessor or not.
page: A contrivance, as a band, pin, snap, or the like, to hold the skirt of a woman's dress from the ground.

A serving boy; formerly, a youth attending a person of high degree, especially at courts, as a position of honor and education; now commonly, in England, a youth employed for doing errands, waiting on the door, and similar service in households; in the United States, a boy employed to wait upon the members of a legislative body.
A track along which pallets carrying newly molded bricks are conveyed to the hack.
Any one of several species of beautiful South American moths of the genus Urania.
One side of a leaf of a book or manuscript.
painted: Covered or adorned with paint; portrayed in colors.
painter: A rope at the bow of a boat, used to fasten it to anything.
An artist who represents objects or scenes in color on a flat surface, as canvas, plaster, or the like.
One who covers buildings, ships, ironwork, and the like, with paint.
One whose occupation is to paint
painting: A depicting by words; vivid representation in words.
The act or employment of laying on, or adorning with, paints or colors.
The work of the painter; also, any work of art in which objects are represented in color on a flat surface; a colored representation of any object or scene; a picture.
pair: A married couple; a man and wife.
In a mechanism, two elements, or bodies, which are so applied to each other as to mutually constrain relative motion.
To be joined in paris; to couple; to mate, as for breeding.
To engage (one's self) with another of opposite opinions not to vote on a particular question or class of questions.
To suit; to fit, as a counterpart.
palace: Loosely, any unusually magnificent or stately house.
The official residence of a bishop or other distinguished personage.
The residence of a sovereign, including the lodgings of high officers of state, and rooms for business, as well as halls for ceremony and reception.
paper: A sheet, leaf, or piece of such substance.

A substance in the form of thin sheets or leaves intended to be written or printed on, or to be used in wrapping. It is made of rags, straw, bark, wood, or other fibrous material, which is first reduced to pulp, then molded, pressed, and dried.
parish: An ecclesiastical society, usually not bounded by territorial limits, but composed of those persons who choose to unite under the charge of a particular priest, clergyman, or minister; also, loosely, the territory in which the members of a congregation live.
In Louisiana, a civil division corresponding to a county in other States.
That circuit of ground committed to the charge of one parson or vicar, or other minister having cure of souls therein.
The same district, constituting a civil jurisdiction, with its own officers and regulations, as respects the poor, taxes, etc.
park: A partially inclosed basin in which oysters are grown.
A piece of ground inclosed, and stored with beasts of the chase, which a man may have by prescription, or the king's grant.
A tract of ground kept in its natural state, about or adjacent to a residence, as for the preservation of game, for walking, riding, or the like.
parliament: A formal conference on public affairs; a general council; esp., an assembly of representatives of a nation or people having authority to make laws.
A parleying; a discussion; a conference.
In France, before the Revolution of 1789, one of the several principal judicial courts.

The assembly of the three estates of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, viz., the lords spiritual, lords temporal, and the representatives of the commons, sitting in the House of Lords and the House of Commons, constituting the legislature, when summoned by the royal authority to consult on the affairs of the nation, and to enact and repeal laws.
part: A constituent of character or capacity; quality; faculty; talent; -- usually in the plural with a collective sense.
A constituent portion of a living or spiritual whole; a member; an organ; an essential element.
An equal constituent portion; one of several or many like quantities, numbers, etc., into which anything is divided, or of which it is composed; proportional division or ingredient.

One of the portions, equal or unequal, into which anything is divided, or regarded as divided; something less than a whole; a number, quantity, mass, or the like, regarded as going to make up, with others, a larger number, quantity, mass, etc., whether actually separate or not; a piece; a fragment; a fraction; a division; a member; a constituent.
Quarter; region; district; -- usually in the plural.
That which belongs to one, or which is assumed by one, or which falls to one, in a division or apportionment; share; portion; lot; interest; concern; duty; office.
To divide into shares; to divide and distribute; to allot; to apportion; to share.
participate: To impart, or give, or share of.
To partake of; to share in; to receive a part of.
particular: Special or personal peculiarity, trait, or character; individuality; interest, etc.
particularly: In a particular manner; expressly; with a specific reference or interest; in particular; distinctly.
partner: A framework of heavy timber surrounding an opening in a deck, to strengthen it for the support of a mast, pump, capstan, or the like.
partnership: A contract between two or more competent persons for joining together their money, goods, labor, and skill, or any or all of them, under an understanding that there shall be a communion of profit between them, and for the purpose of carrying on a legal trade, business, or adventure.
A division or sharing among partners; joint possession or interest.
party: A number of persons united in opinion or action, as distinguished from, or opposed to, the rest of a community or association; esp., one of the parts into which a people is divided on questions of public policy.
A part of a larger body of company; a detachment; especially (Mil.), a small body of troops dispatched on special service.
Hence, any certain person who is regarded as being opposed or antagonistic to another.
The plaintiff or the defendant in a lawsuit, whether an individual, a firm, or corporation; a litigant.
pass: A movement of the hand over or along anything; the manipulation of a mesmerist.
A thrust or push; an attempt to stab or strike an adversary.
Fig.: a thrust; a sally of wit.
To be suffered to go on; to be tolerated; hence, to continue; to live along.
To decline to take an optional action when it is one's turn, as to decline to bid, or to bet, or to play a card; in euchre, to decline to make the trump.
To emit from the bowels; to evacuate.
To go by without noticing; to omit attention to; to take no note of; to disregard.
To go from one limit to the other of; to spend; to live through; to have experience of; to undergo; to suffer.
To make, as a thrust, punto, etc.

To move or to come into being or under notice; to come and go in consciousness; hence, to take place; to occur; to happen; to come; to occur progressively or in succession; to be present transitorily.
To take a turn with (a line, gasket, etc.), as around a sail in furling, and make secure.
passenger: A passer or passer-by; a wayfarer.
A traveler by some established conveyance, as a coach, steamboat, railroad train, etc.
passing: The act of one who, or that which, passes; the act of going by or away.
past: A former time or state; a state of things gone by.
Beyond, in position, or degree; further than; beyond the reach or influence of.
paul: An Italian silver coin. See Paolo.
pay: Hence, figuratively: To compensate justly; to requite according to merit; to reward; to punish; to retort or retaliate upon.
To cover, as bottom of a vessel, a seam, a spar, etc., with tar or pitch, or waterproof composition of tallow, resin, etc.; to smear.
To discharge or fulfill, as a duy; to perform or render duty, as that which has been promised.

To discharge, as a debt, demand, or obligation, by giving or doing what is due or required; to deliver the amount or value of to the person to whom it is owing; to discharge a debt by delivering (money owed).
peace: A state of quiet or tranquillity; freedom from disturbance or agitation; calm; repose
Exemption from, or cessation of, war with public enemies.
Exemption from, or subjection of, agitating passions; tranquillity of mind or conscience.
Public quiet, order, and contentment in obedience to law.
Reconciliation; agreement after variance; harmony; concord.
To make or become quiet; to be silent; to stop.
peak: The extremity of an anchor fluke; the bill.
The narrow part of a vessel's bow, or the hold within it.
To acquire sharpness of figure or features; hence, to look thin or sicky.
people: One's subjects; fellow citizens; companions; followers.
The body of persons who compose a community, tribe, nation, or race; an aggregate of individuals forming a whole; a community; a nation.
perform: To carry through; to bring to completion; to achieve; to accomplish; to execute; to do.
To represent; to act; to play; as in drama.
performance: That which is performed or accomplished; a thing done or carried through; an achievement; a deed; an act; a feat; esp., an action of an elaborate or public character.
perhaps: By chance; peradventure; perchance; it may be.
