period: A complete sentence, from one full stop to another; esp., a well-proportioned, harmonious sentence.
One of several similar sets of figures or terms usually marked by points or commas placed at regular intervals, as in numeration, in the extraction of roots, and in circulating decimals.
The punctuation point [.] that marks the end of a complete sentence, or of an abbreviated word.
The termination or completion of a revolution, cycle, series of events, single event, or act; hence, a limit; a bound; an end; a conclusion.
The time of the exacerbation and remission of a disease, or of the paroxysm and intermission.
person: A character or part, as in a play; a specific kind or manifestation of individual character, whether in real life, or in literary or dramatic representation; an assumed character.
A living, self-conscious being, as distinct from an animal or a thing; a moral agent; a human being; a man, woman, or child.
A shoot or bud of a plant; a polyp or zooid of the compound Hydrozoa Anthozoa, etc.; also, an individual, in the narrowest sense, among the higher animals.
Among Trinitarians, one of the three subdivisions of the Godhead (the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost); an hypostasis.

One of three relations or conditions (that of speaking, that of being spoken to, and that of being spoken of) pertaining to a noun or a pronoun, and thence also to the verb of which it may be the subject.
personal: Done in person; without the intervention of another.
Pertaining to human beings as distinct from things.
personnel: The body of persons employed in some public service, as the army, navy, etc.; -- distinguished from materiel.
peter: A common baptismal name for a man. The name of one of the apostles,
phase: Any one point or portion in a recurring series of changes, as in the changes of motion of one of the particles constituting a wave or vibration; one portion of a series of such changes, in distinction from a contrasted portion, as the portion on one side of a position of equilibrium, in contrast with that on the opposite side.
That which is exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests, especially any one among different and varying appearances of the same object.
philosophy: A particular philosophical system or theory; the hypothesis by which particular phenomena are explained.
Literally, the love of, including the search after, wisdom; in actual usage, the knowledge of phenomena as explained by, and resolved into, causes and reasons, powers and laws.
The course of sciences read in the schools.
piano: Soft; -- a direction to the performer to execute a certain passage softly, and with diminished volume of tone. (Abbrev. p.)
picture: A representation of anything (as a person, a landscape, a building) upon canvas, paper, or other surface, produced by means of painting, drawing, engraving, photography, etc.; a representation in colors. By extension, a figure; a model.
The art of painting; representation by painting.
To draw or paint a resemblance of; to delineate; to represent; to form or present an ideal likeness of; to bring before the mind.
piece: An individual; -- applied to a person as being of a certain nature or quality; often, but not always, used slightingly or in contempt.
Any one thing conceived of as apart from other things of the same kind; an individual article; a distinct single effort of a series; a definite performance
One of the superior men, distinguished from a pawn.
To unite by a coalescence of parts; to fit together; to join.
To unite; to join; to combine.
pilot: An instrument for detecting the compass error.
Figuratively: A guide; a director of another through a difficult or unknown course.
Figuratively: To guide, as through dangers or difficulties.
One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.
Specifically, a person duly qualified, and licensed by authority, to conduct vessels into and out of a port, or in certain waters, for a fixed rate of fees.
To direct the course of, as of a ship, where navigation is dangerous.
place: A broad way in a city; an open space; an area; a court or short part of a street open only at one end.
A definite position or passage of a document.
A position which is occupied and held; a dwelling; a mansion; a village, town, or city; a fortified town or post; a stronghold; a region or country.
Any portion of space regarded as measured off or distinct from all other space, or appropriated to some definite object or use; position; ground; site; spot; rarely, unbounded space.
Position in the heavens, as of a heavenly body; -- usually defined by its right ascension and declination, or by its latitude and longitude.
Rank; degree; grade; order of priority, advancement, dignity, or importance; especially, social rank or position; condition; also, official station; occupation; calling.
Reception; effect; -- implying the making room for.
To attribute; to ascribe; to set down.
Vacated or relinquished space; room; stead (the departure or removal of another being or thing being implied).
plan: A method; a way of procedure; a custom.
To form a delineation of; to draught; to represent, as by a diagram.
plant: A bush, or young tree; a sapling; hence, a stick or staff.
A plan; an artifice; a swindle; a trick.

A vegetable; an organized living being, generally without feeling and voluntary motion, and having, when complete, a root, stem, and leaves, though consisting sometimes only of a single leafy expansion, or a series of cellules, or even a single cellule.
An oyster which has been bedded, in distinction from one of natural growth.
To engender; to generate; to set the germ of.
To set in the ground for growth, as a young tree, or a vegetable with roots.
To set up; to install; to instate.
platform: A light deck, usually placed in a section of the hold or over the floor of the magazine. See Orlop.
A place laid out after a model.
A plat; a plan; a sketch; a model; a pattern. Used also figuratively.

Any flat or horizontal surface; especially, one that is raised above some particular level, as a framework of timber or boards horizontally joined so as to form a roof, or a raised floor, or portion of a floor; a landing; a dais; a stage, for speakers, performers, or workmen; a standing place.
To form a plan of; to model; to lay out.
play: A dramatic composition; a comedy or tragedy; a composition in which characters are represented by dialogue and action.
Any exercise, or series of actions, intended for amusement or diversion; a game.
Performance on an instrument of music.
To act on the stage; to personate a character.
To act with levity or thoughtlessness; to trifle; to be careless.
To act; to behave; to practice deception.
To engage in sport or lively recreation; to exercise for the sake of amusement; to frolic; to spot.
To move gayly; to wanton; to disport.
player: One who plays on an instrument of music.
One who plays, or amuses himself; one without serious aims; an idler; a trifler.
plot: A plan or draught of a field, farm, estate, etc., drawn to a scale.
In fiction, the story of a play, novel, romance, or poem, comprising a complication of incidents which are gradually unfolded, sometimes by unexpected means.
To contrive a plan or stratagem; to scheme.
To form a scheme of mischief against another, especially against a government or those who administer it; to conspire.
To plan; to scheme; to devise; to contrive secretly.
plus: Hence, in a literary sense, additional; real; actual.
More, required to be added; positive, as distinguished from negative; -- opposed to minus.
poetry: The art of apprehending and interpreting ideas by the faculty of imagination; the art of idealizing in thought and in expression.
point: A a string or lace used to tie together certain parts of the dress.
A dot or mark used to designate certain tones or time
A dot placed at the right hand of a note, to raise its value, or prolong its time, by one half, as to make a whole note equal to three half notes, a half note equal to three quarter notes.
A fielder who is stationed on the off side, about twelve or fifteen yards from, and a little in advance of, the batsman.
A small matter; a trifle; a least consideration; a punctilio.
A tyne or snag of an antler.

An indefinitely small space; a mere spot indicated or supposed. Specifically: (Geom.) That which has neither parts nor magnitude; that which has position, but has neither length, breadth, nor thickness, -- sometimes conceived of as the limit of a line; that by the motion of which a line is conceived to be produced.
An indivisible portion of time; a moment; an instant; hence, the verge.
Anything which tapers to a sharp, well-defined termination. Specifically: A small promontory or cape; a tract of land extending into the water beyond the common shore line.
Hence, to direct the attention or notice of.
One of the several different parts of the escutcheon. See Escutcheon.
One of the spaces on a backgammon board.
That which pricks or pierces; the sharp end of anything, esp. the sharp end of a piercing instrument, as a needle or a pin.
The mark made by the end of a sharp, piercing instrument, as a needle; a prick.
To approximate to the surface; to head; -- said of an abscess.
To fill up and finish the joints of (a wall), by introducing additional cement or mortar, and bringing it to a smooth surface.
To indicate or discover by a fixed look, as game.
To indicate the presence of game by fixed and steady look, as certain hunting dogs do.
police: A judicial and executive system, for the government of a city, town, or district, for the preservation of rights, order, cleanliness, health, etc., and for the enforcement of the laws and prevention of crime; the administration of the laws and regulations of a city, incorporated town, or borough.
That which concerns the order of the community; the internal regulation of a state.
The cleaning of a camp or garrison, or the state / a camp as to cleanliness.
The organized body of civil officers in a city, town, or district, whose particular duties are the preservation of good order, the prevention and detection of crime, and the enforcement of the laws.
policy: A ticket or warrant for money in the public funds.
Management or administration based on temporal or material interest, rather than on principles of equity or honor; hence, worldly wisdom; dexterity of management; cunning; stratagem.
Prudence or wisdom in the management of public and private affairs; wisdom; sagacity; wit.
The method by which any institution is administered; system of management; course.

The settled method by which the government and affairs of a nation are, or may be, administered; a system of public or official administration, as designed to promote the external or internal prosperity of a state.

The writing or instrument in which a contract of insurance is embodied; an instrument in writing containing the terms and conditions on which one party engages to indemnify another against loss arising from certain hazards, perils, or risks to which his person or property may be exposed. See Insurance.
To regulate by laws; to reduce to order.
polish: A smooth, glossy surface, usually produced by friction; a gloss or luster.
Anything used to produce a gloss.
political: Having, or conforming to, a settled system of administration.
politician: One versed or experienced in the science of government; one devoted to politics; a statesman.
politics: The management of a political party; the conduct and contests of parties with reference to political measures or the administration of public affairs; the advancement of candidates to office; in a bad sense, artful or dishonest management to secure the success of political candidates or parties; political trickery.

The science of government; that part of ethics which has to do with the regulation and government of a nation or state, the preservation of its safety, peace, and prosperity, the defense of its existence and rights against foreign control or conquest, the augmentation of its strength and resources, and the protection of its citizens in their rights, with the preservation and improvement of their morals.
poor: A small European codfish (Gadus minutus); -- called also power cod.
Destitute of property; wanting in material riches or goods; needy; indigent.
Destitute of such qualities as are desirable, or might naturally be expected
Free from self-assertion; not proud or arrogant; meek.
So completely destitute of property as to be entitled to maintenance from the public.
Worthy of pity or sympathy; -- used also sometimes as a term of endearment, or as an expression of modesty, and sometimes as a word of contempt.
pop: To enter, or issue forth, with a quick, sudden movement; to move from place to place suddenly; to dart; -- with in, out, upon, off, etc.
pope: A parish priest, or a chaplain, of the Greek Church.
The bishop of Rome, the head of the Roman Catholic Church. See Note under Cardinal.
popular: Devoted to the common people; studious of the favor of the populace.
Suitable to common people; easy to be comprehended; not abstruse; familiar; plain.
population: The act or process of populating; multiplication of inhabitants.
port: A passageway in a machine, through which a fluid, as steam, water, etc., may pass, as from a valve to the interior of the cylinder of a steam engine; an opening in a valve seat, or valve face.
A place where ships may ride secure from storms; a sheltered inlet, bay, or cove; a harbor; a haven. Used also figuratively.
In law and commercial usage, a harbor where vessels are admitted to discharge and receive cargoes, from whence they depart and where they finish their voyages.
portion: A part assigned; allotment; share; fate.
A part considered by itself, though not actually cut off or separated from the whole.
That which is divided off or separated, as a part from a whole; a separated part of anything.
The part of an estate given to a child or heir, or descending to him by law, and distributed to him in the settlement of the estate; an inheritance.
portuguese: A native or inhabitant of Portugal; people of Portugal.
positive: A picture in which the lights and shades correspond in position with those of the original, instead of being reversed, as in a negative.
Fully assured; confident; certain; sometimes, overconfident; dogmatic; overbearing; -- said of persons.
Having a real position, existence, or energy; existing in fact; real; actual; -- opposed to negative.
Hence, basic; metallic; not acid; -- opposed to negative, and said of metals, bases, and basic radicals.
Prescribed by express enactment or institution; settled by arbitrary appointment; said of laws.
That which is capable of being affirmed; reality.
That which settles by absolute appointment.
post: A military station; the place at which a soldier or a body of troops is stationed; also, the troops at such a station.
A size of printing and writing paper. See the Table under Paper.
Haste or speed, like that of a messenger or mail carrier.
Hired to do what is wrong; suborned.
The piece of ground to which a sentinel's walk is limited.
The place at which anything is stopped, placed, or fixed; a station.
To enter (a name) on a list, as for service, promotion, or the like.
To inform; to give the news to; to make (one) acquainted with the details of a subject; -- often with up.
To rise and sink in the saddle, in accordance with the motion of the horse, esp. in trotting.
potential: Being potent; endowed with energy adequate to a result; efficacious; influential.
Existing in possibility, not in actuality.
The energy of an electrical charge measured by its power to do work; hence, the degree of electrification as referred to some standard, as that of the earth; electro-motive force.
poverty: The quality or state of being poor or indigent; want or scarcity of means of subsistence; indigence; need.
power: A military or naval force; an army or navy; a great host.
An authority enabling a person to dispose of an interest vested either in himself or in another person; ownership by appointment.

The degree to which a lens, mirror, or any optical instrument, magnifies; in the telescope, and usually in the microscope, the number of times it multiplies, or augments, the apparent diameter of an object; sometimes, in microscopes, the number of times it multiplies the apparent surface.
The exercise of a faculty; the employment of strength; the exercise of any kind of control; influence; dominion; sway; command; government.
powerful: Large; capacious; -- said of veins of ore.
practice: A easy and concise method of applying the rules of arithmetic to questions which occur in trade and business.
Actual performance; application of knowledge; -- opposed to theory.
Customary or constant use; state of being used.
Skill or dexterity acquired by use; expertness.
Skillful or artful management; dexterity in contrivance or the use of means; art; stratagem; artifice; plot; -- usually in a bad sense.
The form, manner, and order of conducting and carrying on suits and prosecutions through their various stages, according to the principles of law and the rules laid down by the courts.
To apply theoretical science or knowledge, esp. by way of experiment; to exercise or pursue an employment or profession, esp. that of medicine or of law.
To make use of; to employ.
premier: Most ancient; -- said of the peer bearing the oldest title of his degree.
The first minister of state; the prime minister.
presence: An assembly, especially of person of rank or nobility; noble company.
The place in which one is present; the part of space within one's ken, call, influence, etc.; neighborhood without the intervention of anything that forbids intercourse.
The state of being present, or of being within sight or call, or at hand; -- opposed to absence.
The whole of the personal qualities of an individual; person; personality; especially, the person of a superior, as a sovereign.
present: Being at hand, within reach or call, within certain contemplated limits; -- opposed to absent.
Hence: To endow; to bestow a gift upon; to favor, as with a donation; also, to court by gifts.
To appear at the mouth of the uterus so as to be perceptible to the finger in vaginal examination; -- said of a part of an infant during labor.
To make a gift of; to bestow; to give, generally in a formal or ceremonious manner; to grant; to confer.
To nominate for support at a public school or other institution .
To nominate to an ecclesiastical benefice; to offer to the bishop or ordinary as a candidate for institution.
To pass over, esp. in a ceremonious manner; to give in charge or possession; to deliver; to make over.
president: A protector; a guardian; a presiding genius.
Occupying the first rank or chief place; having the highest authority; presiding.
One who is elected or appointed to preside; a presiding officer, as of a legislative body.
The chief officer of a corporation, company, institution, society, or the like.
press: A commission to force men into public service, particularly into the navy.
A multitude of individuals crowded together; / crowd of single things; a throng.
An East Indian insectivore (Tupaia ferruginea). It is arboreal in its habits, and has a bushy tail. The fur is soft, and varies from rusty red to maroon and to brownish black.
To exercise very powerful or irresistible influence upon or over; to constrain; to force; to compel.
To move on with urging and crowding; to make one's way with violence or effort; to bear onward forcibly; to crowd; to throng; to encroach.
pressure: The action of a force against some obstacle or opposing force; a force in the nature of a thrust, distributed over a surface, often estimated with reference to the upon a unit's area.
prevent: To be beforehand with; to anticipate.
To come before the usual time.
To go before; to precede; hence, to go before as a guide; to direct.
To intercept; to hinder; to frustrate; to stop; to thwart.
price: The sum or amount of money at which a thing is valued, or the value which a seller sets on his goods in market; that for which something is bought or sold, or offered for sale; equivalent in money or other means of exchange; current value or rate paid or demanded in market or in barter; cost.
priest: A presbyter; one who belongs to the intermediate order between bishop and deacon. He is authorized to perform all ministerial services except those of ordination and confirmation.
One who is authorized to consecrate the host and to say Mass; but especially, one of the lowest order possessing this power.
primarily: In a primary manner; in the first place; in the first place; in the first intention; originally.
primary: First in order of time or development or in intention; primitive; fundamental; original.
Illustrating, possessing, or characterized by, some quality or property in the first degree; having undergone the first stage of substitution or replacement.
One of the large feathers on the distal joint of a bird's wing. See Plumage, and Illust. of Bird.
That which stands first in order, rank, or importance; a chief matter.
prime: An inch, as composed of twelve seconds in the duodecimal system; -- denoted by [']. See 2d Inch, n., 1.

Any number expressing the combining weight or equivalent of any particular element; -- so called because these numbers were respectively reduced to their lowest relative terms on the fixed standard of hydrogen as 1.
Early; blooming; being in the first stage.
That which is first in quantity; the most excellent portion; the best part.
The first of the chief guards.
The first part; the earliest stage; the beginning or opening, as of the day, the year, etc.; hence, the dawn; the spring.
The morning; specifically (R. C. Ch.), the first canonical hour, succeeding to lauds.
The spring of life; youth; hence, full health, strength, or beauty; perfection.
To be renewed, or as at first.
To serve as priming for the charge of a gun.
To trim or prune, as trees.
To work so that foaming occurs from too violent ebullition, which causes water to become mixed with, and be carried along with, the steam that is formed; -- said of a steam boiler.
prince: The one of highest rank; one holding the highest place and authority; a sovereign; a monarch; -- originally applied to either sex, but now rarely applied to a female.
principal: A capital sum of money, placed out at interest, due as a debt or used as a fund; -- so called in distinction from interest or profit.
A chief obligor, promisor, or debtor, -- as distinguished from a surety.
A thing of chief or prime importance; something fundamental or especially conspicuous.

In English organs the chief open metallic stop, an octave above the open diapason. On the manual it is four feet long, on the pedal eight feet. In Germany this term corresponds to the English open diapason.
One of turrets or pinnacles of waxwork and tapers with which the posts and center of a funeral hearse were formerly crowned.
One who employs another to act for him, -- as distinguished from an agent.
The chief actor in a crime, or an abettor who is present at it, -- as distinguished from an accessory.
The first two long feathers of a hawk's wing.
prison: A place where persons are confined, or restrained of personal liberty; hence, a place or state o/ confinement, restraint, or safe custody.
Specifically, a building for the safe custody or confinement of criminals and others committed by lawful authority.
private: A common soldier; a soldier below the grade of a noncommissioned officer.
A secret message; a personal unofficial communication.
One not invested with a public office.
prize: A contest for a reward; competition.
A lever; a pry; also, the hold of a lever.
An honor or reward striven for in a competitive contest; anything offered to be competed for, or as an inducement to, or reward of, effort.
Anything captured by a belligerent using the rights of war; esp., property captured at sea in virtue of the rights of war, as a vessel.
Anything worth striving for; a valuable possession held or in prospect.
That which is taken from another; something captured; a thing seized by force, stratagem, or superior power.
That which may be won by chance, as in a lottery.
To move with a lever; to force up or open; to pry.
To set or estimate the value of; to appraise; to price; to rate.
To value highly; to estimate to be of great worth; to esteem.
pro: A Latin preposition signifying for, before, forth.
For, on, or in behalf of, the affirmative side; -- in contrast with con.
probably: In a probable manner; in likelihood.
problem: A question proposed for solution; a matter stated for examination or proof; hence, a matter difficult of solution or settlement; a doubtful case; a question involving doubt.
Anything which is required to be done; as, in geometry, to bisect a line, to draw a perpendicular; or, in algebra, to find an unknown quantity.
process: A statement of events; a narrative.
Any marked prominence or projecting part, especially of a bone; anapophysis.
The act of proceeding; continued forward movement; procedure; progress; advance.

The whole course of proceedings in a cause real or personal, civil or criminal, from the beginning to the end of the suit; strictly, the means used for bringing the defendant into court to answer to the action; -- a generic term for writs of the class called judicial.
produce: To yield or furnish appropriate offspring, crops, effects, consequences, or results.
producer: A furnace for producing combustible gas which is used for fuel.
One who grows agricultural products, or manufactures crude materials into articles of use.
One who produces, brings forth, or generates.
production: The act of lengthening out or prolonging.
professor: One who professed, or makes open declaration of, his sentiments or opinions; especially, one who makes a public avowal of his belief in the Scriptures and his faith in Christ, and thus unites himself to the visible church.
programme: That which is written or printed as a public notice or advertisement; a scheme; a prospectus; especially, a brief outline or explanation of the order to be pursued, or the subjects embraced, in any public exercise, performance, or entertainment; a preliminary sketch.
progress: A journey of state; a circuit; especially, one made by a sovereign through parts of his own dominions.
A moving or going forward; a proceeding onward; an advance
In the growth of an animal or plant; increase.
project: To throw or cast forward; to shoot forth.
promote: To urge on or incite another, as to strife; also, to inform against a person.
property: All the adjuncts of a play except the scenery and the dresses of the actors; stage requisites.
An acquired or artificial quality; that which is given by art, or bestowed by man; as, the poem has the properties which constitute excellence.
The exclusive right of possessing, enjoying, and disposing of a thing; ownership; title.
To invest which properties, or qualities.
protection: A theory, or a policy, of protecting the producers in a country from foreign competition in the home market by the imposition of such discriminating duties on goods of foreign production as will restrict or prevent their importation; -- opposed to free trade.
A writing that protects or secures from molestation or arrest; a pass; a safe-conduct; a passport.
That which protects or preserves from injury; a defense; a shield; a refuge.
protein: A body now known as alkali albumin, but originally considered to be the basis of all albuminous substances, whence its name.
provide: To appoint to an ecclesiastical benefice before it is vacant. See Provisor.
To furnish; to supply; -- formerly followed by of, now by with.
To look out for in advance; to procure beforehand; to get, collect, or make ready for future use; to prepare.
To supply; to afford; to contribute.
province: A country or region dependent on a distant authority; a portion of an empire or state, esp. one remote from the capital.
A country or region, more or less remote from the city of Rome, brought under the Roman government; a conquered country beyond the limits of Italy.
A region of country; a tract; a district.
The proper or appropriate business or duty of a person or body; office; charge; jurisdiction; sphere.
provincial: A monastic superior, who, under the general of his order, has the direction of all the religious houses of the same fraternity in a given district, called a province of the order.
Exhibiting the ways or manners of a province; characteristic of the inhabitants of a province; not cosmopolitan; countrified; not polished; rude; hence, narrow; illiberal.
publication: The act of offering a book, pamphlet, engraving, etc., to the public by sale or by gratuitous distribution.
purchase: Acquisition of lands or tenements by other means than descent or inheritance, namely, by one's own act or agreement.

Any mechanical hold, or advantage, applied to the raising or removing of heavy bodies, as by a lever, a tackle, capstan, and the like; also, the apparatus, tackle, or device by which the advantage is gained.
That which is obtained for a price in money or its equivalent.
That which is obtained, got, or acquired, in any manner, honestly or dishonestly; property; possession; acquisition.
The acquisition of title to, or properly in, anything for a price; buying for money or its equivalent.
The act of seeking and acquiring property.
The act of seeking, getting, or obtaining anything.
To acquire by any means except descent or inheritance.
To expiate by a fine or forfeit.
To pursue and obtain; to acquire by seeking; to gain, obtain, or acquire.
To put forth effort to obtain anything; to strive; to exert one's self.
purpose: That which a person sets before himself as an object to be reached or accomplished; the end or aim to which the view is directed in any plan, measure, or exertion; view; aim; design; intention; plan.
To propose, as an aim, to one's self; to determine upon, as some end or object to be accomplished; to intend; to design; to resolve; -- often followed by an infinitive or dependent clause.
To set forth; to bring forward.
put: A rustic; a clown; an awkward or uncouth person.
To convey coal in the mine, as from the working to the tramway.
To incite; to entice; to urge; to constrain; to oblige.
To lay down; to give up; to surrender.
To steer; to direct one's course; to go.
quality: Special or temporary character; profession; occupation; assumed or asserted rank, part, or position.
Superior birth or station; high rank; elevated character.
The condition of being of such and such a sort as distinguished from others; nature or character relatively considered, as of goods; character; sort; rank.
quarter: A small upright timber post, used in partitions; -- in the United States more commonly called stud.
A station at which officers and men are posted in battle; -- usually in the plural.
A term of study in a seminary, college, etc, etc.; properly, a fourth part of the year, but often longer or shorter.
One of the divisions of an escutcheon when it is divided into four portions by a horizontal and a perpendicular line meeting in the fess point.
Place of lodging or temporary residence; shelter; entertainment; -- usually in the plural.
Proper station; specific place; assigned position; special location.
That part of a boot or shoe which forms the side, from the heel to the vamp.
That part on either side of a horse's hoof between the toe and heel, being the side of the coffin.
The encampment on one of the principal passages round a place besieged, to prevent relief and intercept convoys.
The fourth of a hundred-weight, being 25 or 28 pounds, according as the hundredweight is reckoned at 100 or 112 pounds.
To drive a carriage so as to prevent the wheels from going into the ruts, or so that a rut shall be between the wheels.
To lodge; to have a temporary residence.
Treatment shown by an enemy; mercy; especially, the act of sparing the life a conquered enemy; a refraining from pushing one's advantage to extremes.
queen: A male homosexual, esp. one who is effeminate or dresses in women's clothing.
The fertile, or fully developed, female of social bees, ants, and termites.
The most powerful, and except the king the most important, piece in a set of chessmen.
question: Examination with reference to a decisive result; investigation; specifically, a judicial or official investigation; also, examination under torture.
Talk; conversation; speech; speech.
That which is asked; inquiry; interrogatory; query.
To argue; to converse; to dispute.
To doubt of; to be uncertain of; to query.
To talk to; to converse with.
quickly: Speedily; with haste or celerity; soon; without delay; quick.
quite: To a great extent or degree; very; very much; considerably.
race: A channel or guide along which a shuttle is driven back and forth, as in a loom, sewing machine, etc.
A progress; a course; a movement or progression.
A variety of such fixed character that it may be propagated by seed.
Competitive action of any kind, especially when prolonged; hence, career; course of life.
Esp., swift progress; rapid course; a running.
Peculiar flavor, taste, or strength, as of wine; that quality, or assemblage of qualities, which indicates origin or kind, as in wine; hence, characteristic flavor; smack.
The descendants of a common ancestor; a family, tribe, people, or nation, believed or presumed to belong to the same stock; a lineage; a breed.
To run too fast at times, as a marine engine or screw, when the screw is lifted out of water by the action of a heavy sea.
racing: a. & n. from Race, v. t. & i.
rail: A bar of steel or iron, forming part of the track on which the wheels roll. It is usually shaped with reference to vertical strength, and is held in place by chairs, splices, etc.
A bar of timber or metal, usually horizontal or nearly so, extending from one post or support to another, as in fences, balustrades, staircases, etc.
A horizontal piece in a frame or paneling. See Illust. of Style.
An outer cloak or covering; a neckerchief for women.
Any one of numerous species of limicoline birds of the family Rallidae, especially those of the genus Rallus, and of closely allied genera. They are prized as game birds.
The light, fencelike structures of wood or metal at the break of the deck, and elsewhere where such protection is needed.
The stout, narrow plank that forms the top of the bulwarks.
To flow forth; to roll out; to course.
To use insolent and reproachful language; to utter reproaches; to scoff; -- followed by at or against, formerly by on.
railway: A road or way consisting of one or more parallel series of iron or steel rails, patterned and adjusted to be tracks for the wheels of vehicles, and suitably supported on a bed or substructure.

The road, track, etc., with all the lands, buildings, rolling stock, franchises, etc., pertaining to them and constituting one property; as, a certain railroad has been put into the hands of a receiver.
raised: Leavened; made with leaven, or yeast; -- used of bread, cake, etc., as distinguished from that made with cream of tartar, soda, etc. See Raise, v. t., 4.
ran: Yarns coiled on a spun-yarn winch.
range: A bolting sieve to sift meal.
A place where shooting, as with cannons or rifles, is practiced.
A wandering or roving; a going to and fro; an excursion; a ramble; an expedition.
An aggregate of individuals in one rank or degree; an order; a class.
An extended cooking apparatus of cast iron, set in brickwork, and affording conveniences for various ways of cooking; also, a kind of cooking stove.
In the public land system of the United States, a row or line of townships lying between two successive meridian lines six miles apart.
Sometimes, less properly, the trajectory of a shot or projectile.
The horizontal distance to which a shot or other projectile is carried.
The region within which a plant or animal naturally lives.
The step of a ladder; a rung.
To be native to, or to live in; to frequent.
To place (as a single individual) among others in a line, row, or order, as in the ranks of an army; -- usually, reflexively and figuratively, (in the sense) to espouse a cause, to join a party, etc.
To rove at large; to wander without restraint or direction; to roam.
To separate into parts; to sift.
rank: A line of soldiers ranged side by side; -- opposed to file. See 1st File, 1 (a).
To be ranged; to be set or disposed, as in a particular degree, class, order, or division.
To place abreast, or in a line.
To range in a particular class, order, or division; to class; also, to dispose methodically; to place in suitable classes or order; to classify.
rate: Established portion or measure; fixed allowance.
The class of a merchant vessel for marine insurance, determined by its relative safety as a risk, as A1, A2, etc.
To chide with vehemence; to scold; to censure violently.
To set a certain estimate on; to value at a certain price or degree.
rather: On the other hand; to the contrary of what was said or suggested; instead.
reach: An artifice to obtain an advantage.

An extended portion of land or water; a stretch; a straight portion of a stream or river, as from one turn to another; a level stretch, as between locks in a canal; an arm of the sea extending up into the land.
Extent; stretch; expanse; hence, application; influence; result; scope.
Hence, to extend an action, effort, or influence to; to penetrate to; to pierce, or cut, as far as.
The pole or rod which connects the hind axle with the forward bolster of a wagon.
The power of stretching out or extending action, influence, or the like; power of attainment or management; extent of force or capacity.
To arrive at by effort of any kind; to attain to; to gain; to be advanced to.
To arrive at; to come to; to get as far as.
To extend in dimension, time, amount, action, influence, etc., so as to touch, attain to, or be equal to, something.
To extend; to stretch; to thrust out; to put forth, as a limb, a member, something held, or the like.
To sail on the wind, as from one point of tacking to another, or with the wind nearly abeam.
To strain after something; to make efforts.
reaction: An action induced by vital resistance to some other action; depression or exhaustion of vital force consequent on overexertion or overstimulation; heightened activity and overaction succeeding depression or shock.
Any action in resisting other action or force; counter tendency; movement in a contrary direction; reverse action.
Backward tendency or movement after revolution, reform, or great progress in any direction.
The force which a body subjected to the action of a force from another body exerts upon the latter body in the opposite direction.
read: Hence, to know fully; to comprehend.
Saying; sentence; maxim; hence, word; advice; counsel. See Rede.
To discover or understand by characters, marks, features, etc.; to learn by observation.
To tell; to declare; to recite.
reading: A lecture or prelection; public recital.
Manner of reciting, or acting a part, on the stage; way of rendering.
The act of one who reads; perusal; also, printed or written matter to be read.
The way in which anything reads; force of a word or passage presented by a documentary authority; lection; version.
real: A small Spanish silver coin; also, a denomination of money of account, formerly the unit of the Spanish monetary system.
Having an assignable arithmetical or numerical value or meaning; not imaginary.
Relating to things, not to persons.
reality: That which is real; an actual existence; that which is not imagination, fiction, or pretense; that which has objective existence, and is not merely an idea.
The state or quality of being real; actual being or existence of anything, in distinction from mere appearance; fact.
really: In a real manner; with or in reality; actually; in truth.
rear: Specifically, the part of an army or fleet which comes last, or is stationed behind the rest.
The back or hindmost part; that which is behind, or last in order; -- opposed to front.
To rise up on the hind legs, as a horse; to become erect.
reason: A thought or a consideration offered in support of a determination or an opinion; a just ground for a conclusion or an action; that which is offered or accepted as an explanation; the efficient cause of an occurrence or a phenomenon; a motive for an action or a determination; proof, more or less decisive, for an opinion or a conclusion; principle; efficient cause; final cause; ground of argument.
Hence: To carry on a process of deduction or of induction, in order to convince or to confute; to formulate and set forth propositions and the inferences from them; to argue.
To exercise the rational faculty; to deduce inferences from premises; to perform the process of deduction or of induction; to ratiocinate; to reach conclusions by a systematic comparison of facts.
receive: Hence: To gain the knowledge of; to take into the mind by assent to; to give admission to; to accept, as an opinion, notion, etc.; to embrace.
To admit; to take in; to hold; to contain; to have capacity for; to be able to take in.
To allow, as a custom, tradition, or the like; to give credence or acceptance to.
To bat back (the ball) when served.
To take from a thief, as goods known to be stolen.
reception: Acceptance, as of an opinion or doctrine.
recognition: The act of recognizing, or the state of being recognized; acknowledgment; formal avowal; knowledge confessed or avowed; notice.
record: An authentic official copy of a document which has been entered in a book, or deposited in the keeping of some officer designated by law.
That which serves to perpetuate a knowledge of acts or events; a monument; a memorial.
To recall to mind; to recollect; to remember; to meditate.
To repeat; to recite; to sing or play.
To sing or repeat a tune.
red: The color of blood, or of that part of the spectrum farthest from violet, or a tint resembling these.
reduce: To bring or lead back to any former place or condition.
reference: A work, or a passage in a work, to which one is referred.
One of whom inquires can be made as to the integrity, capacity, and the like, of another.
One who, or that which, is referred to.
The act of submitting a matter in dispute to the judgment of one or more persons for decision.
The process of sending any matter, for inquiry in a cause, to a master or other officer, in order that he may ascertain facts and report to the court.
regiment: A body of men, either horse, foot, or artillery, commanded by a colonel, and consisting of a number of companies, usually ten.
Government; mode of ruling; rule; authority; regimen.
region: One of the grand districts or quarters into which any space or surface, as of the earth or the heavens, is conceived of as divided; hence, in general, a portion of space or territory of indefinite extent; country; province; district; tract.
The upper air; the sky; the heavens.
Tract, part, or space, lying about and including anything; neighborhood; vicinity; sphere.
register: A certificate issued by the collector of customs of a port or district to the owner of a vessel, containing the description of a vessel, its name, ownership, and other material facts. It is kept on board the vessel, to be used as an evidence of nationality or as a muniment of title.
A contrivance for automatically noting the performance of a machine or the rapidity of a process.

A lid, stopper, or sliding plate, in a furnace, stove, etc., for regulating the admission of air to the fuel; also, an arrangement containing dampers or shutters, as in the floor or wall of a room or passage, or in a chimney, for admitting or excluding heated air, or for regulating ventilation.
A record containing a list and description of the merchant vessels belonging to a port or customs district.
A stop or set of pipes in an organ.
A written account or entry; an official or formal enumeration, description, or record; a memorial record; a list or roll; a schedule.
The correspondence of pages, columns, or lines on the opposite or reverse sides of the sheet.
The inner part of the mold in which types are cast.
The part of a telegraphic apparatus which records automatically the message received.
To enroll; to enter in a list.
regular: A member of any religious order or community who has taken the vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, and who has been solemnly recognized by the church.
A soldier belonging to a permanent or standing army; -- chiefly used in the plural.
regularly: In a regular manner; in uniform order; methodically; in due order or time.
reign: Hence, to be predominant; to prevail.
To have superior or uncontrolled dominion; to rule.
relationship: The state of being related by kindred, affinity, or other alliance.
relatively: In a relative manner; in relation or respect to something else; not absolutely.
release: A giving up or relinquishment of some right or claim; a conveyance of a man's right in lands or tenements to another who has some estate in possession; a quitclaim.
Discharge from obligation or responsibility, as from debt, penalty, or claim of any kind; acquittance.
Relief from care, pain, or any burden.
The act of letting loose or freeing, or the state of being let loose or freed; liberation or discharge from restraint of any kind, as from confinement or bondage.
The act of opening the exhaust port to allow the steam to escape.
To lease again; to grant a new lease of; to let back.
To let loose again; to set free from restraint, confinement, or servitude; to give liberty to, or to set at liberty; to let go.
To relieve from something that confines, burdens, or oppresses, as from pain, trouble, obligation, penalty.
religion: Specifically, conformity in faith and life to the precepts inculcated in the Bible, respecting the conduct of life and duty toward God and man; the Christian faith and practice.
Strictness of fidelity in conforming to any practice, as if it were an enjoined rule of conduct.
religious: A person bound by monastic vows, or sequestered from secular concern, and devoted to a life of piety and religion; a monk or friar; a nun.
remain: That which is left of a human being after the life is gone; relics; a dead body.
The posthumous works or productions, esp. literary works, of one who is dead; as, Cecil's
To await; to be left to.
To continue unchanged in place, form, or condition, or undiminished in quantity; to abide; to stay; to endure; to last.

To stay behind while others withdraw; to be left after others have been removed or destroyed; to be left after a number or quantity has been subtracted or cut off; to be left as not included or comprised.
report: A sketch, or a fully written account, of a speech, debate, or the proceedings of a public meeting, legislative body, etc.
A story or statement circulating by common talk; a rumor; hence, fame; repute; reputation.
An account or statement of the results of examination or inquiry made by request or direction; relation.
To furnish in writing an account of a speech, the proceedings at a meeting, the particulars of an occurrence, etc., for publication.
To make minutes of, as a speech, or the doings of a public body; to write down from the lips of a speaker.
To return or repeat, as sound; to echo.
represent: To bring a sensation of into the mind or sensorium; to cause to be known, felt, or apprehended; to present.
To exhibit to another mind in language; to show; to give one's own impressions and judgement of; to bring before the mind; to set forth; sometimes, to give an account of; to describe.
To form or image again in consciousness, as an object of cognition or apprehension (something which was originally apprehended by direct presentation). See Presentative, 3.
To present again or anew; to present by means of something standing in the place of; to exhibit the counterpart or image of; to typify.
representative: A member of the lower or popular house in a State legislature, or in the national Congress.
A species or variety which, in any region, takes the place of a similar one in another region.
An agent, deputy, or substitute, who supplies the place of another, or others, being invested with his or their authority.
Fitted to represent; exhibiting a similitude.
One who represents, or stands in the place of, another.
One who, or that which, represents (anything); that which exhibits a likeness or similitude.
Similar in general appearance, structure, and habits, but living in different regions; -- said of certain species and varieties.
That which presents the full character of the type of a group.
republic: A state in which the sovereign power resides in the whole body of the people, and is exercised by representatives elected by them; a commonwealth. Cf. Democracy, 2.
republican: A South African weaver bird (Philetaerus socius). These weaver birds build many nests together, under a large rooflike shelter, which they make of straw.
The American cliff swallow. The cliff swallows build their nests side by side, many together.
request: A state of being desired or held in such estimation as to be sought after or asked for; demand.
The act of asking for anything desired; expression of desire or demand; solicitation; prayer; petition; entreaty.
research: To search or examine with continued care; to seek diligently.
reserve: Funds kept on hand to meet liabilities.
Hence, to keep in store for future or special use; to withhold from present use for another purpose or time; to keep; to retain.
Restraint of freedom in words or actions; backwardness; caution in personal behavior.
The act of reserving, or keeping back; reservation.
To keep back; to retain; not to deliver, make over, or disclose.
To make an exception of; to except.
residence: That which falls to the bottom of liquors; sediment; also, refuse; residuum.
The place where anything rests permanently.
The place where one resides; an abode; a dwelling or habitation; esp., a settled or permanent home or domicile.
resigned: Submissive; yielding; not disposed to resist or murmur.
resistance: A means or method of resisting; that which resists.
The act of resisting; opposition, passive or active.
respectively: Partially; with respect to private views.
response: A kind of anthem sung after the lessons of matins and some other parts of the office.
A repetition of the given subject in a fugue by another part on the fifth above or fourth below.
Reply to an objection in formal disputation.
The answer of the people or congregation to the priest or clergyman, in the litany and other parts of divine service.
rest: A projection from the right side of the cuirass, serving to support the lance.
A set or game at tennis.
A short pause in reading verse; a c/sura.
A surplus held as a reserved fund by a bank to equalize its dividends, etc.; in the Bank of England, the balance of assets above liabilities.
Hence, freedom from everything which wearies or disturbs; peace; security.
Silence in music or in one of its parts; the name of the character that stands for such silence. They are named as notes are, whole, half, quarter,etc.
That which is left, or which remains after the separation of a part, either in fact or in contemplation; remainder; residue.
The striking of a balance at regular intervals in a running account.
Those not included in a proposition or description; the remainder; others.
To be free from whanever wearies or disturbs; to be quiet or still.
To be left; to remain; to continue to be.
To cease from action or motion, especially from action which has caused weariness; to desist from labor or exertion.
To place, as on a support; to cause to lean.
To sleep; to slumber; hence, poetically, to be dead.
result: The decision or determination of a council or deliberative assembly; a resolve; a decree.
To proceed, spring, or rise, as a consequence, from facts, arguments, premises, combination of circumstances, consultation, thought, or endeavor.
retirement: A place of seclusion or privacy; a place to which one withdraws or retreats; a private abode.
return: A payment; a remittance; a requital.
Hence, to elect according to the official report of the election officers.
The certificate of an officer stating what he has done in execution of a writ, precept, etc., indorsed on the document.
The profit on, or advantage received from, labor, or an investment, undertaking, adventure, etc.
The rendering back or delivery of writ, precept, or execution, to the proper officer or court.
The sending back of a commission with the certificate of the commissioners.
The turnings and windings of a trench or mine.
To bat (the ball) back over the net.
To come back, or begin again, after an interval, regular or irregular; to appear again.
To convey into official custody, or to a general depository.
To give in requital or recompense; to requite.
To go back in thought, narration, or argument.
To report, or bring back and make known.
To revert; to pass back into possession.
To speak in answer; to reply; to respond.
To turn back; to go or come again to the same place or condition.
review: A critical examination of a publication, with remarks; a criticism; a critique.
A lesson studied or recited for a second time.
A periodical containing critical essays upon matters of interest, as new productions in literature, art, etc.
An inspection, as of troops under arms or of a naval force, by a high officer, for the purpose of ascertaining the state of discipline, equipments, etc.
The judicial examination of the proceedings of a lower court by a higher.
To go over and examine critically or deliberately.
To reconsider; to revise, as a manuscript before printing it, or a book for a new edition.
To retrace; to go over again.
To view or see again; to look back on.
revolution: A fundamental change in political organization, or in a government or constitution; the overthrow or renunciation of one government, and the substitution of another, by the governed.
The space measured by the regular return of a revolving body; the period made by the regular recurrence of a measure of time, or by a succession of similar events.
rich: Having an abundance of material possessions; possessed of a large amount of property; well supplied with land, goods, or money; wealthy; opulent; affluent; -- opposed to poor.
right: A true statement; freedom from error of falsehood; adherence to truth or fact.
According to any rule of art; correctly.
Characterized by reality or genuineness; real; actual; not spurious.
Conformed to the constitution of man and the will of God, or to justice and equity; not deviating from the true and just; according with truth and duty; just; true.
In some legislative bodies of Europe (as in France), those members collectively who are conservatives or monarchists. See Center, 5.
Privilege or immunity granted by authority.
That to which one has a just claim.
That which justly belongs to one; that which one has a claim to possess or own; the interest or share which anyone has in a piece of property; title; claim; interest; ownership.
That which one has a natural claim to exact.
The outward or most finished surface, as of a piece of cloth, a carpet, etc.
The straight course; adherence to duty; obedience to lawful authority, divine or human; freedom from guilt, -- the opposite of moral wrong.
Well placed, disposed, or adjusted; orderly; well regulated; correctly done.
ring: A chime, or set of bells harmonically tuned.
A circle, or a circular line, or anything in the form of a circular line or hoop.
A circular area in which races are or run or other sports are performed; an arena.
A clique; an exclusive combination of persons for a selfish purpose, as to control the market, distribute offices, obtain contracts, etc.
An elastic band partly or wholly encircling the spore cases of ferns. See Illust. of Sporangium.
An inclosed space in which pugilists fight; hence, figuratively, prize fighting.
Any loud sound; the sound of numerous voices; a sound continued, repeated, or reverberated.
The plane figure included between the circumferences of two concentric circles.
The solid generated by the revolution of a circle, or other figure, about an exterior straight line (as an axis) lying in the same plane as the circle or other figure.
To continue to sound or vibrate; to resound.
To practice making music with bells.
To repeat often, loudly, or earnestly.
To rise in the air spirally.
To sound, as a bell or other sonorous body, particularly a metallic one.
rise: In various figurative senses.
Increase of sound; a swelling of the voice.
Increase; advance; augmentation, as of price, value, rank, property, fame, and the like.
The spring of a fish to seize food (as a fly) near the surface of the water.
To appear above the horizont, as the sun, moon, stars, and the like.
To ascend from the grave; to come to life.
To ascend or float in a fluid, as gases or vapors in air, cork in water, and the like.
To attain to a better social position; to be promoted; to excel; to succeed.
To be lifted, or to admit of being lifted, from the imposing stone without dropping any of the type; -- said of a form.
To become excited, opposed, or hostile; to go to war; to take up arms; to rebel.
To become larger; to swell; -- said of a boil, tumor, and the like.
To become louder, or higher in pitch, as the voice.
To become of higher value; to increase in price.
To come to mind; to be suggested; to occur.
To come; to offer itself.
To have the aspect or the effect of rising.
To increase in amount; to enlarge; as, his expenses rose beyond his expectations.
To increase in intensity; -- said of heat.
To increase in power or fury; -- said of wind or a storm, and hence, of passion.
To increase in size, force, or value; to proceed toward a climax.
To retire; to give up a siege.
To swell or puff up in the process of fermentation; to become light, as dough, and the like.
To terminate an official sitting; to adjourn; as, the committee rose after agreeing to the report.
risk: Hazard of loss; liabillity to loss in property.
Hazard; danger; peril; exposure to loss, injury, or destruction.
river: A large stream of water flowing in a bed or channel and emptying into the ocean, a sea, a lake, or another stream; a stream larger than a rivulet or brook.
road: A journey, or stage of a journey.
A place where one may ride; an open way or public passage for vehicles, persons, and animals; a track for travel, forming a means of communication between one city, town, or place, and another.
rock: A distaff used in spinning; the staff or frame about which flax is arranged, and from which the thread is drawn in spinning.
A large concreted mass of stony material; a large fixed stone or crag. See Stone.
Any natural deposit forming a part of the earth's crust, whether consolidated or not, including sand, earth, clay, etc., when in natural beds.
The striped bass. See under Bass.
To move or be moved backward and forward; to be violently agitated; to reel; to totter.
roman: Expressed in letters, not in figures, as I., IV., i., iv., etc.; -- said of numerals, as distinguished from the Arabic numerals, 1, 4, etc.
Upright; erect; -- said of the letters or kind of type ordinarily used, as distinguished from Italic characters.
roof: The surface or bed of rock immediately overlying a bed of coal or a flat vein.
To inclose in a house; figuratively, to shelter.
room: A particular portion of space appropriated for occupancy; a place to sit, stand, or lie; a seat.
Especially, space in a building or ship inclosed or set apart by a partition; an apartment or chamber.
Place or position in society; office; rank; post; station; also, a place or station once belonging to, or occupied by, another, and vacated.
rose: A flower and shrub of any species of the genus Rosa, of which there are many species, mostly found in the morthern hemispere
The card of the mariner's compass; also, a circular card with radiating lines, used in other instruments.
round: A brewer's vessel in which the fermentation is concluded, the yeast escaping through the bunghole.
A course of action or conduct performed by a number of persons in turn, or one after another, as if seated in a circle.
A general discharge of firearms by a body of troops in which each soldier fires once.
A series of duties or tasks which must be performed in turn, and then repeated.
A vessel filled, as for drinking.
By or in a circuit; by a course longer than the direct course; back to the starting point.
Complete and consistent; fair; just; -- applied to conduct.
Full and smoothly expanded; not defective or abrupt; finished; polished; -- said of style, or of authors with reference to their style.
Full; complete; not broken; not fractional; approximately in even units, tens, hundreds, thousands, etc.; -- said of numbers.
The step of a ladder; a rundle or rung; also, a crosspiece which joins and braces the legs of a chair.
The time during which prize fighters or boxers are in actual contest without an intermission, as prescribed by their rules; a bout.
Through a circle, as of friends or houses.
To bring to fullness or completeness; to complete; hence, to bring to a fit conclusion.
route: The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.
row: A noisy, turbulent quarrel or disturbance; a brawl.
royal: A small sail immediately above the topgallant sail.
An old English coin. See Rial.
One of the upper or distal branches of an antler, as the third and fourth tynes of the antlers of a stag.
Printing and writing papers of particular sizes. See under paper, n.
rule: A measuring instrument consisting of a graduated bar of wood, ivory, metal, or the like, which is usually marked so as to show inches and fractions of an inch, and jointed so that it may be folded compactly.
A thin plate of metal (usually brass) of the same height as the type, and used for printing lines, as between columns on the same page, or in tabular work.
An order regulating the practice of the courts, or an order made between parties to an action or a suit.
Systematic method or practice; as, my ule is to rise at six o'clock.
The act of ruling; administration of law; government; empire; authority; control.
To control or direct by influence, counsel, or persuasion; to guide; -- used chiefly in the passive.
To control the will and actions of; to exercise authority or dominion over; to govern; to manage.
To have power or command; to exercise supreme authority; -- often followed by over.
Uniform or established course of things.
run: A continuing urgent demand; especially, a pressure on a bank or treasury for payment of its notes.
A pair or set of millstones.
A pleasure excursion; a trip.
A small stream; a brook; a creek.
Specifically, of a horse: To move rapidly in a gait in which each leg acts in turn as a propeller and a supporter, and in which for an instant all the limbs are gathered in the air under the body.
State of being current; currency; popularity.
The act of migrating, or ascending a river to spawn; -- said of fish; also, an assemblage or school of fishes which migrate, or ascend a river for the purpose of spawning.
The aftermost part of a vessel's hull where it narrows toward the stern, under the quarter.
The greatest degree of swiftness in marching. It is executed upon the same principles as the double-quick, but with greater speed.

The horizontal distance to which a drift may be carried, either by license of the proprietor of a mine or by the nature of the formation; also, the direction which a vein of ore or other substance takes.
To be charged with, or to contain much of, while flowing; as, the rivers ran blood.
To be in form thus, as a combination of words.
To be played on the stage a number of successive days or nights; as, the piece ran for six months.
To be popularly known; to be generally received.
To become fluid; to melt; to fuse.
To cause to pass, or evade, offical restrictions; to smuggle; -- said of contraband or dutiable goods.
To creep, as serpents.
To discuss; to continue to think or speak about something; -- with on.
To drive or force; to cause, or permit, to be driven.
To flee, as from fear or danger.
To go swiftly; to pass at a swift pace; to hasten.
To make numerous drafts or demands for payment, as upon a bank; -- with on.
To make progress; to proceed; to pass.
To migrate or move in schools; -- said of fish; esp., to ascend a river in order to spawn.
To move rapidly by springing steps so that there is an instant in each step when neither foot touches the ground; -- so distinguished from walking in athletic competition.

To move, proceed, advance, pass, go, come, etc., swiftly, smoothly, or with quick action; -- said of things animate or inanimate. Hence, to flow, glide, or roll onward, as a stream, a snake, a wagon, etc.; to move by quicker action than in walking, as a person, a horse, a dog.
To proceed along a surface; to extend; to spread.
To pursue in thought; to carry in contemplation.
To put at hazard; to venture; to risk.
To sail before the wind, in distinction from reaching or sailing closehauled; -- said of vessels.
To sew, as a seam, by passing the needle through material in a continuous line, generally taking a series of stitches on the needle at the same time.
To steal off; to depart secretly.
To tease with sarcasms and ridicule.
To tend, as to an effect or consequence; to incline.
running: The discharge from an ulcer or other sore.
russia: A country of Europe and Asia.
russian: A native or inhabitant of Russia; the language of Russia.
safety: Freedom from whatever exposes one to danger or from liability to cause danger or harm; safeness; hence, the quality of making safe or secure, or of giving confidence, justifying trust, insuring against harm or loss, etc.
The condition or state of being safe; freedom from danger or hazard; exemption from hurt, injury, or loss.
saint: A person sanctified; a holy or godly person; one eminent for piety and virtue; any true Christian, as being redeemed and consecrated to God.
One of the blessed in heaven.
sale: Public disposal to the highest bidder, or exposure of goods in market; auction.
The act of selling; the transfer of property, or a contract to transfer the ownership of property, from one person to another for a valuable consideration, or for a price in money.
same: Just mentioned, or just about to be mentioned.
Not different or other; not another or others; identical; unchanged.
save: Except; excepting; not including; leaving out; deducting; reserving; saving.
Specifically, to deliver from sin and its penalty; to rescue from a state of condemnation and spiritual death, and bring into a state of spiritual life.
To avoid unnecessary expense or expenditure; to prevent waste; to be economical.
To hinder from doing, suffering, or happening; to obviate the necessity of; to prevent; to spare.
To hold possession or use of; to escape loss of.
To keep from being spent or lost; to secure from waste or expenditure; to lay up; to reserve.
To rescue from something undesirable or hurtful; to prevent from doing something; to spare.
saw: A saying; a proverb; a maxim.

An instrument for cutting or dividing substances, as wood, iron, etc., consisting of a thin blade, or plate, of steel, with a series of sharp teeth on the edge, which remove successive portions of the material by cutting and tearing.
say: A delicate kind of serge, or woolen cloth.
A kind of silk or satin.
A speech; something said; an expression of opinion; a current story; a maxim or proverb.
To announce as a decision or opinion; to state positively; to assert; hence, to form an opinion upon; to be sure about; to be determined in mind as to.
To speak; to express an opinion; to make answer; to reply.
To utter or express in words; to tell; to speak; to declare; as, he said many wise things.
saying: That which is said; a declaration; a statement, especially a proverbial one; an aphorism; a proverb.
scale: A ladder; a series of steps; a means of ascending.
An incrustation deposit on the inside of a vessel in which water is heated, as a steam boiler.
Hence, anything graduated, especially when employed as a measure or rule, or marked by lines at regular intervals.

One of the small, thin, membranous, bony or horny pieces which form the covering of many fishes and reptiles, and some mammals, belonging to the dermal part of the skeleton, or dermoskeleton. See Cycloid, Ctenoid, and Ganoid.
The thin metallic side plate of the handle of a pocketknife. See Illust. of Pocketknife.
The thin oxide which forms on the surface of iron forgings. It consists essentially of the magnetic oxide, Fe3O4. Also, a similar coating upon other metals.
To clean, as the inside of a cannon, by the explosion of a small quantity of powder.
To lead up by steps; to ascend.
scene: An assemblage of objects presented to the view at once; a series of actions and events exhibited in their connection; a spectacle; a show; an exhibition; a view.
An exhibition of passionate or strong feeling before others; often, an artifical or affected action, or course of action, done for effect; a theatrical display.

The place, time, circumstance, etc., in which anything occurs, or in which the action of a story, play, or the like, is laid; surroundings amid which anything is set before the imagination; place of occurrence, exhibition, or action.
The structure on which a spectacle or play is exhibited; the part of a theater in which the acting is done, with its adjuncts and decorations; the stage.
schedule: A written or printed scroll or sheet of paper; a document; especially, a formal list or inventory; a list or catalogue annexed to a larger document, as to a will, a lease, a statute, etc.
scheme: A combination of things connected and adjusted by design; a system.
A representation of the aspects of the celestial bodies for any moment or at a given event.
Any lineal or mathematical diagram; an outline.
school: A session of an institution of instruction.
One of the seminaries for teaching logic, metaphysics, and theology, which were formed in the Middle Ages, and which were characterized by academical disputations and subtilties of reasoning.
The disciples or followers of a teacher; those who hold a common doctrine, or accept the same teachings; a sect or denomination in philosophy, theology, science, medicine, politics, etc.
The room or hall in English universities where the examinations for degrees and honors are held.
To tutor; to chide and admonish; to reprove; to subject to systematic discipline; to train.
science: Accumulated and established knowledge, which has been systematized and formulated with reference to the discovery of general truths or the operation of general laws; knowledge classified and made available in work, life, or the search for truth; comprehensive, profound, or philosophical knowledge.
Art, skill, or expertness, regarded as the result of knowledge of laws and principles.
Knowledge; knowledge of principles and causes; ascertained truth of facts.
score: A distance of twenty yards; -- a term used in ancient archery and gunnery.
A line drawn; a groove or furrow.
A notch or incision; especially, one that is made as a tally mark; hence, a mark, or line, made for the purpose of account.
An account or reckoning; account of dues; bill; hence, indebtedness.
The number of points gained by the contestants, or either of them, in any game, as in cards or cricket.

The original and entire draught, or its transcript, of a composition, with the parts for all the different instruments or voices written on staves one above another, so that they can be read at a glance; -- so called from the bar, which, in its early use, was drawn through all the parts.
To engrave, as upon a shield.
To mark or signify by lines or notches; to keep record or account of; to set down; to record; to charge.
screen: A dwarf wall or partition carried up to a certain height for separation and protection, as in a church, to separate the aisle from the choir, or the like.
A long, coarse riddle or sieve, sometimes a revolving perforated cylinder, used to separate the coarser from the finer parts, as of coal, sand, gravel, and the like.
A surface, as that afforded by a curtain, sheet, wall, etc., upon which an image, as a picture, is thrown by a magic lantern, solar microscope, etc.
sea: A great brazen laver in the temple at Jerusalem; -- so called from its size.
The ocean; the whole body of the salt water which covers a large part of the globe.
search: The act of seeking or looking for something; quest; inquiry; pursuit for finding something; examination.
To examine; to try; to put to the test.
To inquire after; to look for; to seek.
To seek; to look for something; to make inquiry, exploration, or examination; to hunt.
season: A period of time not very long; a while; a time.
Hence, to fit for enjoyment; to render agrecable.
To become mature; to grow fit for use; to become adapted to a climate.
To imbue; to tinge or taint.
To qualify by admixture; to moderate; to temper.
To render suitable or appropriate; to prepare; to fit.
seat: Posture, or way of sitting, on horseback.
The place occupied by anything, or where any person or thing is situated, resides, or abides; a site; an abode, a station; a post; a situation.
The place or thing upon which one sits; hence; anything made to be sat in or upon, as a chair, bench, stool, saddle, or the like.
To cause to occupy a post, site, situation, or the like; to station; to establish; to fix; to settle.
second: An article of merchandise of a grade inferior to the best; esp., a coarse or inferior kind of flour.
Immediately following the first; next to the first in order of place or time; hence, occuring again; another; other.
In the duodecimal system of mensuration, the twelfth part of an inch or prime; a line. See Inch, and Prime, n., 8.
One who follows or attends another for his support and aid; a backer; an assistant; specifically, one who acts as another's aid in a duel.
One who, or that which, follows, or comes after; one next and inferior in place, time, rank, importance, excellence, or power.
Specifically, to support, as a motion or proposal, by adding one's voice to that of the mover or proposer.
The interval between any tone and the tone which is represented on the degree of the staff next above it.
To follow in the next place; to succeed; to alternate.
secondary: Pertaining to the second joint of the wing of a bird.
Suceeding next in order to the first; of second place, origin, rank, rank, etc.; not primary; subordinate; not of the first order or rate.
secret: A thing not discovered; what is unknown or unexplained; a mystery.
Something studiously concealed; a thing kept from general knowledge; what is not revealed, or not to be revealed.
The parts which modesty and propriety require to be concealed; the genital organs.
Withdraw from general intercourse or notice; in retirement or secrecy; secluded.
secretary: A person employed to write orders, letters, dispatches, public or private papers, records, and the like; an official scribe, amanuensis, or writer; one who attends to correspondence, and transacts other business, for an association, a public body, or an individual.
A piece of furniture, with conveniences for writing and for the arrangement of papers; an escritoire.
One who keeps, or is intrusted with, secrets.
section: A distinct part of a country or people, community, class, or the like; a part of a territory separated by geographical lines, or of a people considered as distinct.

A distinct part or portion of a book or writing; a subdivision of a chapter; the division of a law or other writing; a paragraph; an article; hence, the character /, often used to denote such a division.
A division of a genus; a group of species separated by some distinction from others of the same genus; -- often indicated by the sign /.
A part of a musical period, composed of one or more phrases. See Phrase.
A part separated from something; a division; a portion; a slice.

The description or representation of anything as it would appear if cut through by any intersecting plane; depiction of what is beyond a plane passing through, or supposed to pass through, an object, as a building, a machine, a succession of strata; profile.
sector: A part of a circle comprehended between two radii and the included arc.
security: An evidence of debt or of property, as a bond, a certificate of stock, etc.; as, government securities.
Freedom from apprehension, anxiety, or care; confidence of power of safety; hence, assurance; certainty.
One who becomes surety for another, or engages himself for the performance of another's obligation.
Something given, deposited, or pledged, to make certain the fulfillment of an obligation, the performance of a contract, the payment of a debt, or the like; surety; pledge.
That which secures or makes safe; protection; guard; defense.
The condition or quality of being secure; secureness.
see: A seat; a site; a place where sovereign power is exercised.
Figuratively: To have intellectual apprehension; to perceive; to know; to understand; to discern; -- often followed by a preposition, as through, or into.
To follow with the eyes, or as with the eyes; to watch; to regard attentivelly; to look after.
To perceive by mental vision; to form an idea or conception of; to note with the mind; to observe; to discern; to distinguish; to understand; to comprehend; to ascertain.
To perceive by the eye; to have knowledge of the existence and apparent qualities of by the organs of sight; to behold; to descry; to view.
selection: The act of selecting, or the state of being selected; choice, by preference.
senate: A body of elders appointed or elected from among the nobles of the nation, and having supreme legislative authority.
An assembly or council having the highest deliberative and legislative functions.
In general, a legislative body; a state council; the legislative department of government.

In some American colleges, a council of elected students, presided over by the president of the college, to which are referred cases of discipline and matters of general concern affecting the students.
The governing body of the Universities of Cambridge and London.
The upper and less numerous branch of a legislature in various countries, as in France, in the United States, in most of the separate States of the United States, and in some Swiss cantons.
senator: A member of the king's council; a king's councilor.
senior: A person who is older than another; one more advanced in life.
Belonging to the final year of the regular course in American colleges, or in professional schools.
One older in office, or whose entrance upon office was anterior to that of another; one prior in grade.
sense: One of two opposite directions in which a line, surface, or volume, may be supposed to be described by the motion of a point, line, or surface.
Perception by the sensory organs of the body; sensation; sensibility; feeling.
Perception through the intellect; apprehension; recognition; understanding; discernment; appreciation.
Sound perception and reasoning; correct judgment; good mental capacity; understanding; also, that which is sound, true, or reasonable; rational meaning.
That which is felt or is held as a sentiment, view, or opinion; judgment; notion; opinion.
sent: obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Send, for sendeth.
separate: To disunite; to divide; to disconnect; to sever; to part in any manner.
To set apart; to select from among others, as for a special use or service.
Unconnected; not united or associated; distinct; -- said of things that have not been connected.
september: The ninth month of the year, containing thurty days.
series: Any comprehensive group of animals or plants including several subordinate related groups.
