serious: Grave in manner or disposition; earnest; thoughtful; solemn; not light, gay, or volatile.
Really intending what is said; being in earnest; not jesting or deceiving.
serve: Hence, to bring forward, arrange, deal, or distribute, as a portion of anything, especially of food prepared for eating; -- often with up; formerly with in.
To be a servant or a slave; to be employed in labor or other business for another; to be in subjection or bondage; to render menial service.
To be in service; to do duty; to discharge the requirements of an office or employment. Specifically, to act in the public service, as a soldier, seaman. etc.
To be of use; to answer a purpose; to suffice; to suit; to be convenient or favorable.
To be subordinate to; to act a secondary part under; to appear as the inferior of; to minister to.
To be suitor to; to profess love to.
To lead off in delivering (the ball).
To lead off in delivering the ball.
To perform domestic offices; to be occupied with household affairs; to prepare and dish up food, etc.
To wind spun yarn, or the like, tightly around (a rope or cable, etc.) so as to protect it from chafing or from the weather. See under Serving.

To work for; to labor in behalf of; to exert one's self continuously or statedly for the benefit of; to do service for; to be in the employment of, as an inferior, domestic, serf, slave, hired assistant, official helper, etc.; specifically, in a religious sense, to obey and worship.
service: A name given to several trees and shrubs of the genus Pyrus, as Pyrus domestica and P. torminalis of Europe, the various species of mountain ash or rowan tree, and the American shad bush (see Shad bush, under Shad). They have clusters of small, edible, applelike berries.
Act of serving or covering. See Serve, v. t., 13.
Duty performed in, or appropriate to, any office or charge; official function; hence, specifically, military or naval duty; performance of the duties of a soldier.
Hence, a musical composition for use in churches.
Profession of respect; acknowledgment of duty owed.
The act of serving the ball.

The act of serving; the occupation of a servant; the performance of labor for the benefit of another, or at another's command; attendance of an inferior, hired helper, slave, etc., on a superior, employer, master, or the like; also, spiritual obedience and love.
The deed of one who serves; labor performed for another; duty done or required; office.
The materials used for serving a rope, etc., as spun yarn, small lines, etc.
Useful office; advantage conferred; that which promotes interest or happiness; benefit; avail.
session: The act of sitting, or the state of being seated.
The actual sitting of a court, council, legislature, etc., or the actual assembly of the members of such a body, for the transaction of business.
set: A number of persons associated by custom, office, common opinion, quality, or the like; a division; a group; a clique.
A piece placed temporarily upon the head of a pile when the latter cannot be reached by the weight, or hammer, except by means of such an intervening piece.
A short steel spike used for driving the head of a nail below the surface.
A young oyster when first attached.
Adjusted; arranged; formed; adapted.
Collectively, the crop of young oysters in any locality.
Hence, to attach or affix (something) to something else, or in or upon a certain place.
In dancing, the number of persons necessary to execute a quadrille; also, the series of figures or movements executed.
That dimension of the body of a type called by printers the width.
That which is staked; a wager; a venture; a stake; hence, a game at venture.
The deflection of a tooth, or of the teeth, of a saw, which causes the the saw to cut a kerf, or make an opening, wider than the blade.
To adorn with something infixed or affixed; to stud; to variegate with objects placed here and there.
To apply one's self; to undertake earnestly; -- now followed by out.
To become fixed or rigid; to be fastened.
To begin to move; to go out or forth; to start; -- now followed by out.
To congeal; to concrete; to solidify.
To fit music to words.
To fit with music; to adapt, as words to notes; to prepare for singing.
To fix firmly; to make fast, permanent, or stable; to render motionless; to give an unchanging place, form, or condition to.
To lower into place and fix solidly, as the blocks of cut stone in a structure.
To make to assume specified place, condition, or occupation; to put in a certain condition or state (described by the accompanying words); to cause to be.
To pass below the horizon; to go down; to decline; to sink out of sight; to come to an end.
To place plants or shoots in the ground; to plant.
To point out the seat or position of, as birds, or other game; -- said of hunting dogs.
To put into a desired position or condition; to adjust; to regulate; to adapt.
To stake at play; to wager; to risk.
To value; to rate; -- with at.
setting: The act of marking the position of game, as a setter does; also, hunting with a setter.
settlement: A disposition of property for the benefit of some person or persons, usually through the medium of trustees, and for the benefit of a wife, children, or other relatives; jointure granted to a wife, or the act of granting it.

A settled place of abode; residence; a right growing out of residence; legal residence or establishment of a person in a particular parish or town, which entitles him to maintenance if a pauper, and subjects the parish or town to his support.
Bestowal, or giving possession, under legal sanction; the act of giving or conferring anything in a formal and permanent manner.
Establishment in life, in business, condition, etc.; ordination or installation as pastor.
Matter that subsides; settlings; sediment; lees; dregs.

That which is bestowed formally and permanently; the sum secured to a person; especially, a jointure made to a woman at her marriage; also, in the United States, a sum of money or other property formerly granted to a pastor in additional to his salary.
That which settles, or is settled, established, or fixed.
The act of setting, or the state of being settled.
The gradual sinking of a building, whether by the yielding of the ground under the foundation, or by the compression of the joints or the material.
seventh: An interval embracing seven diatonic degrees of the scale.
Next in order after the sixth;; coming after six others.
One next in order after the sixth; one coming after six others.
The quotient of a unit divided by seven; one of seven equal parts into which anything is divided.
several: An inclosed or separate place; inclosure.
Each particular taken singly; an item; a detail; an individual.
Persons oe objects, more than two, but not very many.
sex: One of the groups founded on this distinction.
One of the two divisions of organic beings formed on the distinction of male and female.

The distinguishing peculiarity of male or female in both animals and plants; the physical difference between male and female; the assemblage of properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.
shape: A model; a pattern; a mold.
A piece which has been roughly forged nearly to the form it will receive when completely forged or fitted.
A rolled or hammered piece, as a bar, beam, angle iron, etc., having a cross section different from merchant bar.
Form of embodiment, as in words; form, as of thought or conception; concrete embodiment or example, as of some quality.
That which has form or figure; a figure; an appearance; a being.
To design; to prepare; to plan; to arrange.
To form or create; especially, to mold or make into a particular form; to give proper form or figure to.
To image; to conceive; to body forth.
To suit; to be adjusted or conformable.
share: Especially, the part allotted or belonging to one, of any property or interest owned by a number; a portion among others; an apportioned lot; an allotment; a dividend.
The part which opens the ground for the reception of the seed, in a machine for sowing seed.
To cut; to shear; to cleave; to divide.
To have part; to receive a portion; to partake, enjoy, or suffer with others.
To part among two or more; to distribute in portions; to divide.
she: A woman; a female; -- used substantively.
This or that female; the woman understood or referred to; the animal of the female sex, or object personified as feminine, which was spoken of.
ship: Hence, to send away; to get rid of.

Specifically, a vessel furnished with a bowsprit and three masts (a mainmast, a foremast, and a mizzenmast), each of which is composed of a lower mast, a topmast, and a topgallant mast, and square-rigged on all masts. See Illustation in Appendix.
shop: A building or an apartment in which goods, wares, drugs, etc., are sold by retail.
short: Less important, efficaceous, or powerful; not equal or equivalent; less (than); -- with of.
Limited in intellectual power or grasp; not comprehensive; narrow; not tenacious, as memory.
Not distant in time; near at hand.
The part of milled grain sifted out which is next finer than the bran.
shortly: In a short or brief time or manner; soon; quickly.
shot: A missile weapon, particularly a ball or bullet; specifically, whatever is discharged as a projectile from firearms or cannon by the force of an explosive.
A share or proportion; a reckoning; a scot.
The act of shooting; discharge of a firearm or other weapon which throws a missile.
show: A discharge, from the vagina, of mucus streaked with blood, occuring a short time before labor.
A pale blue flame, at the top of a candle flame, indicating the presence of fire damp.
Proud or ostentatious display; parade; pomp.
To exhibit or manifest one's self or itself; to appear; to look; to be in appearance; to seem.
To have a certain appearance, as well or ill, fit or unfit; to become or suit; to appear.
side: A line of descent traced through one parent as distinguished from that traced through another.

The position of a person or party regarded as opposed to another person or party, whether as a rival or a foe; a body of advocates or partisans; a party; hence, the interest or cause which one maintains against another; a doctrine or view opposed to another.
To suit; to pair; to match.
sign: A lettered board, or other conspicuous notice, placed upon or before a building, room, shop, or office to advertise the business there transacted, or the name of the person or firm carrying it on; a publicly displayed token or notice.
A military emblem carried on a banner or a standard.
A motion, an action, or a gesture by which a thought is expressed, or a command or a wish made known.
A remarkable event, considered by the ancients as indicating the will of some deity; a prodigy; an omen.
An event considered by the Jews as indicating the divine will, or as manifesting an interposition of the divine power for some special end; a miracle; a wonder.
An objective evidence of disease; that is, one appreciable by some one other than the patient.
Any character, as a flat, sharp, dot, etc.
Any symbol or emblem which prefigures, typifles, or represents, an idea; a type; hence, sometimes, a picture.
Something serving to indicate the existence, or preserve the memory, of a thing; a token; a memorial; a monument.
That by which anything is made known or represented; that which furnishes evidence; a mark; a token; an indication; a proof.
The twelfth part of the ecliptic or zodiac.
To write one's name, esp. as a token of assent, responsibility, or obligation.
signal: A sign made for the purpose of giving notice to a person of some occurence, command, or danger; also, a sign, event, or watchword, which has been agreed upon as the occasion of concerted action.
A token; an indication; a foreshadowing; a sign.
significant: That which has significance; a sign; a token; a symbol.
silver: Giving a clear, ringing sound soft and clear.
similar: Exactly corresponding; resembling in all respects; precisely like.
Nearly corresponding; resembling in many respects; somewhat like; having a general likeness.
simple: A feast which is not a double or a semidouble.
A part of the apparatus for raising the heddles of a drawloom.
Artless in manner; unaffected; unconstrained; natural; inartificial;; straightforward.
Mere; not other than; being only.
Not given to artifice, stratagem, or duplicity; undesigning; sincere; true.
Weak in intellect; not wise or sagacious; of but moderate understanding or attainments; hence, foolish; silly.
simply: In a simple manner or state; considered in or by itself; without addition; along; merely; solely; barely.
since: From the time of; in or during the time subsequent to; subsequently to; after; -- usually with a past event or time for the object.
In the time past, counting backward from the present; before this or now; ago.
Seeing that; because; considering; -- formerly followed by that.
singer: One who sings; especially, one whose profession is to sing.
One who, or that which, singes.
single: A game with but one player on each side; -- usually in the plural.
A hit by a batter which enables him to reach first base only.
Not deceitful or artful; honest; sincere.
The reeled filaments of silk, twisted without doubling to give them firmness.
To select, as an individual person or thing, from among a number; to choose out from others; to separate.
To sequester; to withdraw; to retire.
To take alone, or one by one.
sir: A respectful title, used in addressing a man, without being prefixed to his name; -- used especially in speaking to elders or superiors; sometimes, also, used in the way of emphatic formality.
A title prefixed to the Christian name of a knight or a baronet.
An English rendering of the LAtin Dominus, the academical title of a bachelor of arts; -- formerly colloquially, and sometimes contemptuously, applied to the clergy.
sister: A woman who is closely allied to, or assocciated with, another person, as in the sdame faith, society, order, or community.
site: The posture or position of a thing.
situation: Position, as regards the conditions and circumstances of the case.
Relative position; circumstances; temporary state or relation at a moment of action which excites interest, as of persons in a dramatic scene.
sixth: Constituting or being one of six equal parts into which anything is divided.
First after the fifth; next in order after the fifth.
The interval embracing six diatonic degrees of the scale.
The next in order after the fifth.
The quotient of a unit divided by six; one of six equal parts which form a whole.
size: A conventional relative measure of dimension, as for shoes, gloves, and other articles made up for sale.
A thin, weak glue used in various trades, as in painting, bookbinding, paper making, etc.
An allowance of food and drink from the buttery, aside from the regular dinner at commons; -- corresponding to battel at Oxford.
Any viscous substance, as gilder's varnish.
To bring or adjust anything exactly to a required dimension, as by cutting.
To order food or drink from the buttery; hence, to enter a score, as upon the buttery book.
To sift, as pieces of ore or metal, in order to separate the finer from the coarser parts.
To swell; to increase the bulk of.
To take the height of men, in order to place them in the ranks according to their stature.
small: Envincing little worth or ability; not large-minded; -- sometimes, in reproach, paltry; mean.
Same as Little go. See under Little, a.
Weak; slender; fine; gentle; soft; not loud.
smith: One who makes or effects anything.
To beat into shape; to forge.
so: In that manner or degree; as, indicated (in any way), or as implied, or as supposed to be known.
It is well; let it be as it is, or let it come to pass; -- used to express assent.
Provided that; on condition that; in case that; if.
social: Consisting in union or mutual intercourse.
Living in communities consisting of males, females, and neuters, as do ants and most bees.
Naturally growing in groups or masses; -- said of many individual plants of the same species.
society: Specifically, the more cultivated portion of any community in its social relations and influences; those who mutually give receive formal entertainments.

The persons, collectively considered, who live in any region or at any period; any community of individuals who are united together by a common bond of nearness or intercourse; those who recognize each other as associates, friends, and acquaintances.
The relationship of men to one another when associated in any way; companionship; fellowship; company.
solo: A tune, air, strain, or a whole piece, played by a single person on an instrument, or sung by a single voice.
something: A part; a portion, more or less; an indefinite quantity or degree; a little.
Anything unknown, undetermined, or not specifically designated; a certain indefinite thing; an indeterminate or unknown event; an unspecified task, work, or thing.
In some degree; somewhat; to some extent; at some distance.
sometimes: At times; at intervals; now and then;occasionally.
son: A male child; the male issue, or offspring, of a parent, father or mother.
A male descendant, however distant; hence, in the plural, descendants in general.
song: A lyrical poem adapted to vocal music; a ballad.
An object of derision; a laughingstock.
More generally, any poetical strain; a poem.
That which is sung or uttered with musical modulations of the voice, whether of a human being or of a bird, insect, etc.
soon: Readily; willingly; -- in this sense used with would, or some other word expressing will.
Without the usual delay; before any time supposed; early.
sound: Fig.: To ascertain, or try to ascertain, the thoughts, motives, and purposes of (a person); to examine; to try; to test; to probe.
Noise without signification; empty noise; noise and nothing else.
To make a noise; to utter a voice; to make an impulse of the air that shall strike the organs of hearing with a perceptible effect.
To measure the depth of; to fathom; especially, to ascertain the depth of by means of a line and plummet.
To signify; to import; to denote.
source: That from which anything comes forth, regarded as its cause or origin; the person from whom anything originates; first cause.
The act of rising; a rise; an ascent.
The rising from the ground, or beginning, of a stream of water or the like; a spring; a fountain.
south: That one of the four cardinal points directly opposite to the north; the region or direction to the right or direction to the right of a person who faces the east.
space: A small piece of metal cast lower than a face type, so as not to receive the ink in printing, -- used to separate words or letters.
Extension, considered independently of anything which it may contain; that which makes extended objects conceivable and possible.
One of the intervals, or open places, between the lines of the staff.
Place, having more or less extension; room.
Quantity of time; an interval between two points of time; duration; time.
The distance or interval between words or letters in the lines, or between lines, as in books.
To walk; to rove; to roam.
special: Particular; peculiar; different from others; extraordinary; uncommon.
species: A component part of compound medicine; a simple.
An officinal mixture or compound powder of any kind; esp., one used for making an aromatic tea or tisane; a tea mixture.
Coin, or coined silver, gold, ot other metal, used as a circulating medium; specie.
In science, a more or less permanent group of existing things or beings, associated according to attributes, or properties determined by scientific observation.
The form or shape given to materials; fashion or shape; form; figure.
Visible or sensible presentation; appearance; a sensible percept received by the imagination; an image.
specific: Anything having peculiar adaption to the purpose to which it is applied.
speech: A particular language, as distinct from others; a tongue; a dialect.
The faculty of uttering articulate sounds or words; the faculty of expressing thoughts by words or articulate sounds; the power of speaking.
formal discourse in public; oration; harangue.
he act of speaking; that which is spoken; words, as expressing ideas; language; conversation.
speed: Prosperity in an undertaking; favorable issue; success.
To cause to be successful, or to prosper; hence, to aid; to favor.
To experience in going; to have any condition, good or ill; to fare.
To fare well; to have success; to prosper.
To hasten to a conclusion; to expedite.
To hurry to destruction; to put an end to; to ruin; to undo.
To make haste; to move with celerity.
To wish success or god fortune to, in any undertaking, especially in setting out upon a journey.
spent: Exhausted of spawn or sperm; -- said especially of fishes.
Exhausted; worn out; having lost energy or motive force.
spirit: A rough breathing; an aspirate, as the letter h; also, a mark to denote aspiration; a breathing.
A solution in alcohol of a volatile principle. Cf. Tincture.
Air set in motion by breathing; breath; hence, sometimes, life itself.
Any one of the four substances, sulphur, sal ammoniac, quicksilver, or arsenic (or, according to some, orpiment).
Any supernatural being, good or bad; an apparition; a specter; a ghost; also, sometimes, a sprite,; a fairy; an elf.
Energy, vivacity, ardor, enthusiasm, courage, etc.

Life, or living substance, considered independently of corporeal existence; an intelligence conceived of apart from any physical organization or embodiment; vital essence, force, or energy, as distinct from matter.
Rum, whisky, brandy, gin, and other distilled liquors having much alcohol, in distinction from wine and malt liquors.
Specifically, a disembodied soul; the human soul after it has left the body.
Tenuous, volatile, airy, or vapory substance, possessed of active qualities.
split: A breach or separation, as in a political party; a division.
A division of a stake happening when two cards of the kind on which the stake is laid are dealt in the same turn.
Specif (Leather Manuf.), one of the sections of a skin made by dividing it into two or more thicknesses.
To be broken; to be dashed to pieces.
To burst; to rupture; to rend; to tear asunder.
To divide or break up into parts or divisions, as by discord; to separate into parts or parties, as a political party; to disunite.
To divulge a secret; to betray confidence; to peach.
To separate into parties or factions.

the division by a player of one hand of blackjack into two hands, allowed when the first two cards dealt to a player have the same value; the player is usually obliged to increase the amount wagered by placing a sum equal to the original bet on the new hand thus created.
to divide one hand of blackjack into two hands, allowed when the first two cards dealt to a player have the same value.
sport: Diversion of the field, as fowling, hunting, fishing, racing, games, and the like, esp. when money is staked.
That which diverts, and makes mirth; pastime; amusement.
That with which one plays, or which is driven about in play; a toy; a plaything; an object of mockery.
To divert; to amuse; to make merry; -- used with the reciprocal pronoun.
To play; to frolic; to wanton.
To practice the diversions of the field or the turf; to be given to betting, as upon races.
To represent by any knd of play.
spot: A mark on a substance or body made by foreign matter; a blot; a place discolored.
A small extent of space; a place; any particular place.
A stain on character or reputation; something that soils purity; disgrace; reproach; fault; blemish.
Commodities, as merchandise and cotton, sold for immediate delivery.
To stain; to blemish; to taint; to disgrace; to tarnish, as reputation; to asperse.
spread: A cloth used as a cover for a table or a bed.
A privilege which one person buys of another, of demanding certain shares of stock at a certain price, or of delivering the same shares of stock at another price, within a time agreed upon.
An unlimited expanse of discontinuous points.
To be made known more extensively, as news.
To extend in length and breadth in all directions, or in breadth only; to be extended or stretched; to expand.
To extend so as to cover something; to extend to a great or grater extent in every direction; to cause to fill or cover a wide or wider space.
spring: A crack or fissure in a mast or yard, running obliquely or transversely.
A leap; a bound; a jump.

A line led from a vessel's quarter to her cable so that by tightening or slacking it she can be made to lie in any desired position; a line led diagonally from the bow or stern of a vessel to some point upon the wharf to which she is moored.
A shoot; a plant; a young tree; also, a grove of trees; woodland.

An elastic body of any kind, as steel, India rubber, tough wood, or compressed air, used for various mechanical purposes, as receiving and imparting power, diminishing concussion, regulating motion, measuring weight or other force.
Any active power; that by which action, or motion, is produced or propagated; cause; origin; motive.
Any source of supply; especially, the source from which a stream proceeds; as issue of water from the earth; a natural fountain.
The season of the year when plants begin to vegetate and grow; the vernal season, usually comprehending the months of March, April, and May, in the middle latitudes north of the equator.
The time of growth and progress; early portion; first stage.
To issue or proceed, as from a parent or ancestor; to result, as from a cause, motive, reason, or principle.
To issue with speed and violence; to move with activity; to dart; to shoot.
To leap; to bound; to jump.
To produce or disclose suddenly or unexpectedly.
To shoot up, out, or forth; to come to the light; to begin to appear; to emerge; as a plant from its seed, as streams from their source, and the like; -often followed by up, forth, or out.
To start or rise suddenly, as from a covert.
squad: A small party of men assembled for drill, inspection, or other purposes.
squadron: A body of cavarly comparising two companies or troops, and averging from one hundred and twenty to two hundred men.
Primarily, a square; hence, a square body of troops; a body of troops drawn up in a square.
square: A parallelogram having four equal sides and four right angles.
An area of four sides, generally with houses on each side; sometimes, a solid block of houses; also, an open place or area for public use, as at the meeting or intersection of two or more streets.
Exact proportion; justness of workmanship and conduct; regularity; rule.
Exactly suitable or correspondent; true; just.
Fig.: The relation of harmony, or exact agreement; equality; level.
The act of squaring, or quarreling; a quarrel.
The corner, or angle, of a figure.
The front of a woman's dress over the bosom, usually worked or embroidered.
The position of planets distant ninety degrees from each other; a quadrate.
To accord or agree exactly; to be consistent with; to conform or agree; to suit; to fit.
To compare with, or reduce to, any given measure or standard.
To form with four sides and four right angles.
To go to opposite sides; to take an attitude of offense or defense, or of defiance; to quarrel.
To hold a quartile position respecting.
To take a boxing attitude; -- often with up, sometimes with off.
stadium: A kind of telemeter for measuring the distance of an object of known dimensions, by observing the angle it subtends; especially (Surveying), a graduated rod used to measure the distance of the place where it stands from an instrument having a telescope, by observing the number of the graduations of the rod that are seen between certain parallel wires (stadia wires) in the field of view of the telescope; -- also called stadia, and stadia rod.
Hence, a race course; especially, the Olympic course for foot races.
staff: A pole upon which a flag is supported and displayed.
A series of verses so disposed that, when it is concluded, the same order begins again; a stanza; a stave.
A stick carried in the hand for support or defense by a person walking; hence, a support; that which props or upholds.
An arbor, as of a wheel or a pinion of a watch.
The five lines and the spaces on which music is written; -- formerly called stave.
The grooved director for the gorget, or knife, used in cutting for stone in the bladder.
stage: A degree of advancement in any pursuit, or of progress toward an end or result.
A floor elevated for the convenience of mechanical work, or the like; a scaffold; a staging.
A floor or story of a house.
A place where anything is publicly exhibited; the scene of any noted action or carrer; the spot where any remarkable affair occurs.
A platform, often floating, serving as a kind of wharf.
An elevated platform on which an orator may speak, a play be performed, an exhibition be presented, or the like.
The floor for scenic performances; hence, the theater; the playhouse; hence, also, the profession of representing dramatic compositions; the drama, as acted or exhibited.
The platform of a microscope, upon which an object is placed to be viewed. See Illust. of Microscope.
stand: A weight of from two hundred and fifty to three hundred pounds, -- used in weighing pitch.
To abide by; to submit to; to suffer.
To adhere to fixed principles; to maintain moral rectitude; to keep from falling into error or vice.
To be at rest in an erect position; to be fixed in an upright or firm position
To be consistent; to agree; to accord.
To be in some particular state; to have essence or being; to be; to consist.
To be or remain as it is; to continue in force; to have efficacy or validity; to abide.
To be supported on the feet, in an erect or nearly erect position; -- opposed to lie, sit, kneel, etc.
To cease from progress; not to proceed; to stop; to pause; to halt; to remain stationary.
To continue upright in a certain locality, as a tree fixed by the roots, or a building resting on its foundation.
To maintain an invincible or permanent attitude; to be fixed, steady, or firm; to take a position in resistance or opposition.
To maintain one's ground; to be acquitted; not to fail or yield; to be safe.
To measure when erect on the feet.
To offer one's self, or to be offered, as a candidate.
To remain without ruin or injury; to hold good against tendencies to impair or injure; to be permanent; to endure; to last; hence, to find endurance, strength, or resources.
To stagnate; not to flow; to be motionless.
standard: A flag; colors; a banner; especially, a national or other ensign.
A tree of natural size supported by its own stem, and not dwarfed by grafting on the stock of a smaller species nor trained upon a wall or trellis.
An inverted knee timber placed upon the deck instead of beneath it, with its vertical branch turned upward from that which lies horizontally.
An upright support, as one of the poles of a scaffold; any upright in framing.
That which is established as a rule or model by authority, custom, or general consent; criterion; test.
The proportion of weights of fine metal and alloy established by authority.
The upper petal or banner of a papilionaceous corolla.
standing: Place to stand in; station; stand.
The act of stopping, or coming to a stand; the state of being erect upon the feet; stand.
star: A person of brilliant and attractive qualities, especially on public occasions, as a distinguished orator, a leading theatrical performer, etc.
A planet supposed to influence one's destiny; (usually pl.) a configuration of the planets, supposed to influence fortune.
One of the innumerable luminous bodies seen in the heavens; any heavenly body other than the sun, moon, comets, and nebulae.
Specifically, a radiated mark in writing or printing; an asterisk [thus, *]; -- used as a reference to a note, or to fill a blank where something is omitted, etc.
start: A convulsive motion, twitch, or spasm; a spasmodic effort.
A tail, or anything projecting like a tail.
The arm, or level, of a gin, drawn around by a horse.
The beginning, as of a journey or a course of action; first motion from a place; act of setting out; the outset; -- opposed to finish.
The curved or inclined front and bottom of a water-wheel bucket.
The handle, or tail, of a plow; also, any long handle.
To bring onto being or into view; to originate; to invent.
To move suddenly, as with a spring or leap, from surprise, pain, or other sudden feeling or emotion, or by a voluntary act.
state: A chair with a canopy above it, often standing on a dais; a seat of dignity; also, the canopy itself.
A form of government which is not monarchial, as a republic.
A political body, or body politic; the whole body of people who are united one government, whatever may be the form of the government; a nation.
Appearance of grandeur or dignity; pomp.
Condition of prosperity or grandeur; wealthy or prosperous circumstances; social importance.
Highest and stationary condition, as that of maturity between growth and decline, or as that of crisis between the increase and the abating of a disease; height; acme.
The circumstances or condition of a being or thing at any given time.
The principal persons in a government.
To set; to settle; to establish.
statement: That which is stated; a formal embodiment in language of facts or opinions; a narrative; a recital.
station: A church in which the procession of the clergy halts on stated days to say stated prayers.
A place calculated for the rendezvous of troops, or for the distribution of them; also, a spot well adapted for offensive measures. Wilhelm (Mil. Dict.).
A place or region to which a government ship or fleet is assigned for duty.
A place to which ships may resort, and where they may anchor safely.
A regular stopping place in a stage road or route; a place where railroad trains regularly come to a stand, for the convenience of passengers, taking in fuel, moving freight, etc.
A state of standing or rest; equilibrium.
An enlargement in a shaft or galley, used as a landing, or passing place, or for the accomodation of a pump, tank, etc.
Post assigned; office; the part or department of public duty which a person is appointed to perform; sphere of duty or occupation; employment.
State; rank; condition of life; social status.
The act of standing; also, attitude or pose in standing; posture.
The fast of the fourth and sixth days of the week, Wednesday and Friday, in memory of the council which condemned Christ, and of his passion.
The headquarters of the police force of any precinct.
The particular place, or kind of situation, in which a species naturally occurs; a habitat.
The place at which an instrument is planted, or observations are made, as in surveying.
statistics: Classified facts respecting the condition of the people in a state, their health, their longevity, domestic economy, arts, property, and political strength, their resources, the state of the country, etc., or respecting any particular class or interest; especially, those facts which can be stated in numbers, or in tables of numbers, or in any tabular and classified arrangement.
The branch of mathematics which studies methods for the calculation of probabilities.
The science which has to do with the collection and classification of certain facts respecting the condition of the people in a state.
stay: A corset stiffened with whalebone or other material, worn by women, and rarely by men.
Cessation of motion or progression; stand; stop.
Hindrance; let; check.
Restraint of passion; moderation; caution; steadiness; sobriety.
Strictly, a part in tension to hold the parts together, or stiffen them.
That which serves as a prop; a support.
To bear up under; to endure; to support; to resist successfully.
To cause to cease; to put an end to.
To change tack; as a ship.
To continue in a state.
To dwell; to tarry; to linger.
To hinde/; to delay; to detain; to keep back.
To hold from proceeding; to withhold; to restrain; to stop; to hold.
To remain for the purpose of; to wait for.
To remain; to continue in a place; to abide fixed for a space of time; to stop; to stand still.
To rest; to depend; to rely; to stand; to insist.
To stop from motion or falling; to prop; to fix firmly; to hold up; to support.
To support from sinking; to sustain with strength; to satisfy in part or for the time.
To tack, as a vessel, so that the other side of the vessel shall be presented to the wind.
To wait; to attend; to forbear to act.
steel: A weapon, as a sword, dagger, etc.
Fig.: Anything of extreme hardness; that which is characterized by sternness or rigor.
To make hard or strong; hence, to make insensible or obdurate.
steve: To pack or stow, as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve.
still: After that; after what is stated.
Comparatively quiet or silent; soft; gentle; low.
In an increasing or additional degree; even more; -- much used with comparatives.
In continuation by successive or repeated acts; always; ever; constantly; uniformly.
In the future as now and before.
Notwithstanding what has been said or done; in spite of what has occured; nevertheless; -- sometimes used as a conjunction. See Synonym of But.
To cause to fall by drops.
To stop, as noise; to silence.
To this time; until and during the time now present; now no less than before; yet.
stock: A block of wood; something fixed and solid; a pillar; a firm support; a post.
A frame of timber, with holes in which the feet, or the feet and hands, of criminals were formerly confined by way of punishment.
A liquid or jelly containing the juices and soluble parts of meat, and certain vegetables, etc., extracted by cooking; -- used in making soup, gravy, etc.
A race or variety in a species.
A thrust with a rapier; a stoccado.
In tectology, an aggregate or colony of persons (see Person), as trees, chains of salpae, etc.
Red and gray bricks, used for the exterior of walls and the front of buildings.
That portion of a pack of cards not distributed to the players at the beginning of certain games, as gleek, etc., but which might be drawn from afterward as occasion required; a bank.
The beater of a fulling mill.
The frame or timbers on which a ship rests while building.
The original progenitor; also, the race or line of a family; the progenitor of a family and his direct descendants; lineage; family.
The part of a tally formerly struck in the exchequer, which was delivered to the person who had lent the king money on account, as the evidence of indebtedness. See Counterfoil.
The principal supporting part; the part in which others are inserted, or to which they are attached.
The stem or branch in which a graft is inserted.
The stem, or main body, of a tree or plant; the fixed, strong, firm part; the trunk.
The support of the block in which an anvil is fixed, or of the anvil itself.
The wood to which the barrel, lock, etc., of a musket or like firearm are secured; also, a long, rectangular piece of wood, which is an important part of several forms of gun carriage.
The wooden or iron crosspiece to which the shank of an anchor is attached. See Illust. of Anchor.
To lay up; to put aside for future use; to store, as merchandise, and the like.
To suffer to retain milk for twenty-four hours or more previous to sale, as cows.
stone: A calculous concretion, especially one in the kidneys or bladder; the disease arising from a calculus.
A weight which legally is fourteen pounds, but in practice varies with the article weighed.
One of the testes; a testicle.
The glass of a mirror; a mirror.
stop: A device, or piece, as a pin, block, pawl, etc., for arresting or limiting motion, or for determining the position to which another part shall be brought.

A member, plain or molded, formed of a separate piece and fixed to a jamb, against which a door or window shuts. This takes the place, or answers the purpose, of a rebate. Also, a pin or block to prevent a drawer from sliding too far.
A point or mark in writing or printing intended to distinguish the sentences, parts of a sentence, or clauses; a mark of punctuation. See Punctuation.

The closing of an aperture in the air passage, or pressure of the finger upon the string, of an instrument of music, so as to modify the tone; hence, any contrivance by which the sounds of a musical instrument are regulated.
The depression in the face of a dog between the skull and the nasal bones. It is conspicuous in the bulldog, pug, and some other breeds.
The diaphragm used in optical instruments to cut off the marginal portions of a beam of light passing through lenses.
To cease from any motion, or course of action.
To point, as a composition; to punctuate.
To regulate the sounds of, as musical strings, by pressing them against the finger board with the finger, or by shortening in any way the vibrating part.
store: Any place where goods are sold, whether by wholesale or retail; a shop.
That which is accumulated, or massed together; a source from which supplies may be drawn; hence, an abundance; a great quantity, or a great number.
To collect as a reserved supply; to accumulate; to lay away.
To furnish; to supply; to replenish; esp., to stock or furnish against a future time.
storm: A heavy shower or fall, any adverse outburst of tumultuous force; violence.
A violent agitation of human society; a civil, political, or domestic commotion; sedition, insurrection, or war; violent outbreak; clamor; tumult.
A violent assault on a fortified place; a furious attempt of troops to enter and take a fortified place by scaling the walls, forcing the gates, or the like.
A violent disturbance of the atmosphere, attended by wind, rain, snow, hail, or thunder and lightning; hence, often, a heavy fall of rain, snow, or hail, whether accompanied with wind or not.
To rage; to be in a violent passion; to fume.
story: A set of rooms on the same floor or level; a floor, or the space between two floors. Also, a horizontal division of a building's exterior considered architecturally, which need not correspond exactly with the stories within.
The relation of an incident or minor event; a short narrative; a tale; especially, a fictitious narrative less elaborate than a novel; a short romance.
street: Originally, a paved way or road; a public highway; now commonly, a thoroughfare in a city or village, bordered by dwellings or business houses.
strength: Intensity; -- said of light or color.
Vigor or style; force of expression; nervous diction; -- said of literary work.
strike: A bushel; four pecks.
A puddler's stirrer.
An instrument with a straight edge for leveling a measure of grain, salt, and the like, scraping off what is above the level of the top; a strickle.
An iron pale or standard in a gate or fence.
An old measure of four bushels.
Fullness of measure; hence, excellence of quality.
The act of quitting work; specifically, such an act by a body of workmen, done as a means of enforcing compliance with demands made on their employer.
The act of striking.
The extortion of money, or the attempt to extort money, by threat of injury; blackmailing.
The horizontal direction of the outcropping edges of tilted rocks; or, the direction of a horizontal line supposed to be drawn on the surface of a tilted stratum. It is at right angles to the dip.
To advance; to cause to go forward; -- used only in past participle.
To become attached to something; -- said of the spat of oysters.
To borrow money of; to make a demand upon; as, he struck a friend for five dollars.
To cut off, as a mortar joint, even with the face of the wall, or inward at a slight angle.
To deliver a quick blow or thrust; to give blows.
To give, as a blow; to impel, as with a blow; to give a force to; to dash; to cast.
To hit upon, or light upon, suddenly; as, my eye struck a strange word; they soon struck the trail.
To lade into a cooler, as a liquor.
To level, as a measure of grain, salt, or the like, by scraping off with a straight instrument what is above the level of the top.
To lower a flag, or colors, in token of respect, or to signify a surrender of a ship to an enemy.
To make an attack; to aim a blow.
To pass with a quick or strong effect; to dart; to penetrate.
To punish; to afflict; to smite.
To quit work in order to compel an increase, or prevent a reduction, of wages.
To run upon a rock or bank; to be stranded; as, the ship struck in the night.
To steal money.
To stroke or pass lightly; to wave.
To touch or hit with some force, either with the hand or with an instrument; to smite; to give a blow to, either with the hand or with any instrument or missile.
To touch; to act by appulse.
strong: Having active physical power, or great physical power to act; having a power of exerting great bodily force; vigorous.

Pertaining to, or designating, a verb which forms its preterit (imperfect) by a variation in the root vowel, and the past participle (usually) by the addition of -en (with or without a change of the root vowel); as in the verbs strive, strove, striven; break, broke, broken; drink, drank, drunk. Opposed to weak, or regular. See Weak.
structure: Manner of building; form; make; construction.
That which is built; a building; esp., a building of some size or magnificence; an edifice.
The act of building; the practice of erecting buildings; construction.
studio: The working room of an artist.
study: A piece for special practice. See Etude.
A setting of the mind or thoughts upon a subject; hence, application of mind to books, arts, or science, or to any subject, for the purpose of acquiring knowledge.
Any particular branch of learning that is studied; any object of attentive consideration.
Mental occupation; absorbed or thoughtful attention; meditation; contemplation.
To apply the mind to books or learning.
To endeavor diligently; to be zealous.
To fix the mind closely upon a subject; to dwell upon anything in thought; to muse; to ponder.
style: A kind of blunt-pointed surgical instrument.
A mode of reckoning time, with regard to the Julian and Gregorian calendars.
A sharp-pointed tool used in engraving; a graver.

An instrument used by the ancients in writing on tablets covered with wax, having one of its ends sharp, and the other blunt, and somewhat expanded, for the purpose of making erasures by smoothing the wax.
Conformity to a recognized standard; manner which is deemed elegant and appropriate, especially in social demeanor; fashion.

Mode of expressing thought in language, whether oral or written; especially, such use of language in the expression of thought as exhibits the spirit and faculty of an artist; choice or arrangement of words in discourse; rhetorical expression.
Mode of presentation, especially in music or any of the fine arts; a characteristic of peculiar mode of developing in idea or accomplishing a result.
The elongated part of a pistil between the ovary and the stigma. See Illust. of Stamen, and of Pistil.
The pin, or gnomon, of a dial, the shadow of which indicates the hour. See Gnomon.
To entitle; to term, name, or call; to denominate.
subject: Hence, that substance or being which is conscious of its own operations; the mind; the thinking agent or principal; the ego. Cf. Object, n., 2.
Obedient; submissive.
Placed or situated under; lying below, or in a lower situation.
That in which any quality, attribute, or relation, whether spiritual or material, inheres, or to which any of these appertain; substance; substratum.
That which is brought under thought or examination; that which is taken up for discussion, or concerning which anything is said or done.
That which is placed under the authority, dominion, control, or influence of something else.
The incident, scene, figure, group, etc., which it is the aim of the artist to represent.
The person who is treated of; the hero of a piece; the chief character.
The principal theme, or leading thought or phrase, on which a composition or a movement is based.
To make subservient.
To submit; to make accountable.
success: That which comes after; hence, consequence, issue, or result, of an endeavor or undertaking, whether good or bad; the outcome of effort.
That which meets with, or one who accomplishes, favorable results, as a play or a player.
The favorable or prosperous termination of anything attempted; the attainment of a proposed object; prosperous issue.
such: Certain; -- representing the object as already particularized in terms which are not mentioned.
Having the particular quality or character specified.
summer: One who sums; one who casts up an account.
The season of the year in which the sun shines most directly upon any region; the warmest period of the year.
sun: Any heavenly body which forms the center of a system of orbs.

The luminous orb, the light of which constitutes day, and its absence night; the central body round which the earth and planets revolve, by which they are held in their orbits, and from which they receive light and heat. Its mean distance from the earth is about 92,500,000 miles, and its diameter about 860,000.
sunday: The first day of the week, -- consecrated among Christians to rest from secular employments, and to religious worship; the Christian Sabbath; the Lord's Day.
supply: A person who fills a place for a time; one who supplies the place of another; a substitute; esp., a clergyman who supplies a vacant pulpit.
An amount of money provided, as by Parliament or Congress, to meet the annual national expenditures; generally in the plural; as, to vote supplies.
That which supplies a want; sufficiency of things for use or want.
The food, and the like, which meets the daily necessities of an army or other large body of men; store; -- used chiefly in the plural; as, the army was discontented for lack of supplies.
To serve instead of; to take the place of.
support: That which upholds, sustains, or keeps from falling, as a prop, a pillar, or a foundation of any kind.
supreme: Highest in authority; holding the highest place in authority, government, or power.
Situated at the highest part or point.
surface: That part of the side which is terminated by the flank prolonged, and the angle of the nearest bastion.
surname: A name or appellation which is added to, or over and above, the baptismal or Christian name, and becomes a family name.
An appellation added to the original name; an agnomen.
surrounding: The things which surround or environ; external or attending circumstances or conditions.
survey: The operation of finding the contour, dimensions, position, or other particulars of, as any part of the earth's surface, whether land or water; also, a measured plan and description of any portion of country, or of a road or line through it.
To examine and ascertain, as the boundaries and royalties of a manor, the tenure of the tenants, and the rent and value of the same.
To view with a scrutinizing eye; to examine.
swiss: A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people of Switzerland.
system: Hence, the whole scheme of created things regarded as forming one complete plan of whole; the universe.
One of the stellate or irregular clusters of intimately united zooids which are imbedded in, or scattered over, the surface of the common tissue of many compound ascidians.
The collection of staves which form a full score. See Score, n.
table: A circular plate of crown glass.
A list of substances and their properties; especially, a list of the elementary substances with their atomic weights, densities, symbols, etc.
A plane surface, supposed to be transparent and perpendicular to the horizon; -- called also perspective plane.
A smooth, flat surface, like the side of a board; a thin, flat, smooth piece of anything; a slab.

An article of furniture, consisting of a flat slab, board, or the like, having a smooth surface, fixed horizontally on legs, and used for a great variety of purposes, as in eating, writing, or working.
Any smooth, flat surface upon which an inscription, a drawing, or the like, may be produced.

Hence, in a great variety of applications: A condensed statement which may be comprehended by the eye in a single view; a methodical or systematic synopsis; the presentation of many items or particulars in one group; a scheme; a schedule.
One of the two, external and internal, layers of compact bone, separated by diploe, in the walls of the cranium.
The arrangement or disposition of the lines which appear on the inside of the hand.
The board on the opposite sides of which backgammon and draughts are played.
The games of backgammon and of draughts.
The part of a machine tool on which the work rests and is fastened.
The upper flat surface of a diamond or other precious stone, the sides of which are cut in angles.
To insert, as one piece of timber into another, by alternate scores or projections from the middle, to prevent slipping; to scarf.
To make board hems in the skirts and bottoms of (sails) in order to strengthen them in the part attached to the boltrope.
To supply with food; to feed.
take: In a somewhat passive sense, to receive; to bear; to endure; to acknowledge; to accept.
In an active sense; To lay hold of; to seize with the hands, or otherwise; to grasp; to get into one's hold or possession; to procure; to seize and carry away; to convey.
The quantity or copy given to a compositor at one time.
To accept, as something offered; to receive; not to refuse or reject; to admit.
To carry; to convey; to deliver to another; to hand over; as, he took the book to the bindery.
To draw; to deduce; to derive.
To gain or secure the interest or affection of; to captivate; to engage; to interest; to charm.
To please; to gain reception; to succeed.
taking: The act of gaining possession; a seizing; seizure; apprehension.
talk: To confer; to reason; to consult.
To utter words; esp., to converse familiarly; to speak, as in familiar discourse, when two or more persons interchange thoughts.
target: A butt or mark to shoot at, as for practice, or to test the accuracy of a firearm, or the force of a projectile.
A conspicuous disk attached to a switch lever to show its position, or for use as a signal.
A kind of small shield or buckler, used as a defensive weapon in war.
The sliding crosspiece, or vane, on a leveling staff.
task: Labor or study imposed by another, often in a definite quantity or amount.
To charge; to tax; as with a fault.
To oppress with severe or excessive burdens; to tax.
tax: A charge or burden laid upon persons or property for the support of a government.
A charge, especially a pecuniary burden which is imposed by authority.
A lesson to be learned; a task.
A sum imposed or levied upon the members of a society to defray its expenses.
A task exacted from one who is under control; a contribution or service, the rendering of which is imposed upon a subject.
teacher: One who instructs others in religion; a preacher; a minister of the gospel; sometimes, one who preaches without regular ordination.
One who teaches or instructs; one whose business or occupation is to instruct others; an instructor; a tutor.
teaching: The act or business of instructing; also, that which is taught; instruction.
team: A group of young animals, especially of young ducks; a brood; a litter.
A number of persons associated together in any work; a gang; especially, a number of persons selected to contend on one side in a match, or a series of matches, in a cricket, football, rowing, etc.

A royalty or privilege granted by royal charter to a lord of a manor, of having, keeping, and judging in his court, his bondmen, neifes, and villains, and their offspring, or suit, that is, goods and chattels, and appurtenances thereto.
Hence, a number of animals moving together.
Two or more horses, oxen, or other beasts harnessed to the same vehicle for drawing, as to a coach, wagon, sled, or the like.
technology: Industrial science; the science of systematic knowledge of the industrial arts, especially of the more important manufactures, as spinning, weaving, metallurgy, etc.
temperature: Constitution; state; degree of any quality.
temple: A contrivence used in a loom for keeping the web stretched transversely.
Fig.: Any place in which the divine presence specially resides.
Hence, among Christians, an edifice erected as a place of public worship; a church.
One of the side bars of a pair of spectacles, jointed to the bows, and passing one on either side of the head to hold the spectacles in place.
The edifice erected at Jerusalem for the worship of Jehovah.
The space, on either side of the head, back of the eye and forehead, above the zygomatic arch and in front of the ear.
ten: One more than nine; twice five.
tennis: A play in which a ball is driven to and fro, or kept in motion by striking it with a racket or with the open hand.
term: A fixed period of time; a prescribed duration
A member of a compound quantity; as, a or b in a + b; ab or cd in ab - cd.
A piece of carved work placed under each end of the taffrail.
A space of time granted to a debtor for discharging his obligation.
In Scotland, the time fixed for the payment of rents.
Propositions or promises, as in contracts, which, when assented to or accepted by another, settle the contract and bind the parties; conditions.
That which limits the extent of anything; limit; extremity; bound; boundary.
The subject or the predicate of a proposition; one of the three component parts of a syllogism, each one of which is used twice.
The time in which a court is held or is open for the trial of causes.
territory: A large extent or tract of land; a region; a country; a district.

In the United States, a portion of the country not included within the limits of any State, and not yet admitted as a State into the Union, but organized with a separate legislature, under a Territorial governor and other officers appointed by the President and Senate of the United States. In Canada, a similarly organized portion of the country not yet formed into a Province.
test: A cupel or cupelling hearth in which precious metals are melted for trial and refinement.
Discriminative characteristic; standard of judgment; ground of admission or exclusion.
That with which anything is compared for proof of its genuineness; a touchstone; a standard.
texas: A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing the pilot house, officers' cabins, etc.
text: A discourse or composition on which a note or commentary is written; the original words of an author, in distinction from a paraphrase, annotation, or commentary.
A verse or passage of Scripture, especially one chosen as the subject of a sermon, or in proof of a doctrine.
Hence, anything chosen as the subject of an argument, literary composition, or the like; topic; theme.
The four Gospels, by way of distinction or eminence.
that: a., conj., & ,In an elliptical sentence to introduce a dependent sentence expressing a wish, or a cause of surprise, indignation, or the like.
a., conj., & ,To introduce a clause employed as the object of the preceding verb, or as the subject or predicate nominative of a verb.
a., conj., & ,To introduce a purpose; -- usually followed by may, or might, and frequently preceded by so, in order, to the end, etc.
theatre: A place or region where great events are enacted; as, the theater of war.
A sphere or scheme of operation.
An edifice in which dramatic performances or spectacles are exhibited for the amusement of spectators; anciently uncovered, except the stage, but in modern times roofed.
Any room adapted to the exhibition of any performances before an assembly, as public lectures, scholastic exercises, anatomical demonstrations, surgical operations, etc.
That which resembles a theater in form, use, or the like; a place rising by steps or gradations, like the seats of a theater.
them: The objective case of they. See They.
theme: A composition or essay required of a pupil.
A noun or verb, not modified by inflections; also, that part of a noun or verb which remains unchanged (except by euphonic variations) in declension or conjugation; stem.
A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
That by means of which a thing is done; means; instrument.
The leading subject of a composition or a movement.
themselves: The plural of himself, herself, and itself. See Himself, Herself, Itself.
then: At that time (referring to a time specified, either past or future).
In that case; in consequence; as a consequence; therefore; for this reason.
Soon afterward, or immediately; next; afterward.
theory: A doctrine, or scheme of things, which terminates in speculation or contemplation, without a view to practice; hypothesis; speculation.
there: To or into that place; thither.
therefore: For that or this reason, referring to something previously stated; for that.
these: The plural of this. See This.
think: To believe; to consider; to esteem.
To employ any of the intellectual powers except that of simple perception through the senses; to exercise the higher intellectual faculties.
To plan or design; to plot; to compass.
To purpose; to intend; to design; to mean.
To reflect upon any subject; to muse; to meditate; to ponder; to consider; to deliberate.
third: The quotient of a unit divided by three; one of three equal parts into which anything is divided.
The sixtieth part of a second of time.
those: The plural of that. See That.
though: Granting, admitting, or supposing that; notwithstanding that; if.
However; nevertheless; notwithstanding; -- used in familiar language, and in the middle or at the end of a sentence.
thought: The act of thinking; the exercise of the mind in any of its higher forms; reflection; cogitation.
three: One more than two; two and one.
through: By means of; by the agency of.
thus: In this or that manner; on this wise.
The commoner kind of frankincense, or that obtained from the Norway spruce, the long-leaved pine, and other conifers.
time: Duration, considered independently of any system of measurement or any employment of terms which designate limited portions thereof.
Hour of travail, delivery, or parturition.
The duration of one's life; the hours and days which a person has at his disposal.
The present life; existence in this world as contrasted with immortal life; definite, as contrasted with infinite, duration.
To measure, as in music or harmony.
title: A church to which a priest was ordained, and where he was to reside.
A name; an appellation; a designation.
A section or division of a subject, as of a law, a book, specif. (Roman & Canon Laws), a chapter or division of a law book.
An appellation of dignity, distinction, or preeminence (hereditary or acquired), given to persons, as duke marquis, honorable, esquire, etc.
An inscription put over or upon anything as a name by which it is known.
That by which a beneficiary holds a benefice.
The inscription in the beginning of a book, usually containing the subject of the work, the author's and publisher's names, the date, etc.
The instrument which is evidence of a right.
The panel for the name, between the bands of the back of a book.
to: Character; condition of being; purpose subserved or office filled.
tom: The knave of trumps at gleek.
top: A bundle or ball of slivers of comkbed wool, from which the noils, or dust, have been taken out.

A child's toy, commonly in the form of a conoid or pear, made to spin on its point, usually by drawing off a string wound round its surface or stem, the motion being sometimes continued by means of a whip.
A plug, or conical block of wood, with longitudital grooves on its surface, in which the strands of the rope slide in the process of twisting.
The chief person; the most prominent one.
The crown of the head, or the hair upon it; the head.
The head, or upper part, of a plant.
The part of a cut gem between the girdle, or circumference, and the table, or flat upper surface.
The utmost degree; the acme; the summit.
To excel; to rise above others.
To perform eminently, or better than before.
To raise one end of, as a yard, so that that end becomes higher than the other.
To rise above; to excel; to outgo; to surpass.
To take off the or upper part of; to crop.
tournament: A mock fight, or warlike game, formerly in great favor, in which a number of combatants were engaged, as an exhibition of their address and bravery; hence, figuratively, a real battle.
toward: Ready to act; forward; bold; valiant.
towards: Near; at hand; in state of preparation.
Tending to; in the direction of; in behalf of.
With direction to, in a moral sense; with respect or reference to; regarding; concerning.
tower: A citadel; a fortress; hence, a defense.
A mass of building standing alone and insulated, usually higher than its diameter, but when of great size not always of that proportion.
A projection from a line of wall, as a fortification, for purposes of defense, as a flanker, either or the same height as the curtain wall or higher.
To rise and overtop other objects; to be lofty or very high; hence, to soar.
town: A farm or farmstead; also, a court or farmyard.

Any collection of houses larger than a village, and not incorporated as a city; also, loosely, any large, closely populated place, whether incorporated or not, in distinction from the country, or from rural communities.
Any number or collection of houses to which belongs a regular market, and which is not a city or the see of a bishop.

Formerly: (a) An inclosure which surrounded the mere homestead or dwelling of the lord of the manor. [Obs.] (b) The whole of the land which constituted the domain. [Obs.] (c) A collection of houses inclosed by fences or walls.
The court end of London;-- commonly with the.
township: In Canada, one of the subdivisions of a county.
In surveys of the public land of the United States, a division of territory six miles square, containing 36 sections.
The district or territory of a town.
track: A mark or impression left by the foot, either of man or beast; trace; vestige; footprint.
A path or course laid out for a race, for exercise, etc.
A tract or area, as of land.
The entire lower surface of the foot; -- said of birds, etc.
To draw along continuously, as a vessel, by a line, men or animals on shore being the motive power; to tow.
trade: A track; a trail; a way; a path; also, passage; travel; resort.
Business of any kind; matter of mutual consideration; affair; dealing.
Refuse or rubbish from a mine.
Specifically: The act or business of exchanging commodities by barter, or by buying and selling for money; commerce; traffic; barter.
To barter, or to buy and sell; to be engaged in the exchange, purchase, or sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or anything else; to traffic; to bargain; to carry on commerce as a business.
To buy and sell or exchange property in a single instance.
To have dealings; to be concerned or associated; -- usually followed by with.
To sell or exchange in commerce; to barter.
tradition: An unwritten code of law represented to have been given by God to Moses on Sinai.
Hence, that which is transmitted orally from father to son, or from ancestors to posterity; knowledge or belief transmitted without the aid of written memorials; custom or practice long observed.
That body of doctrine and discipline, or any article thereof, supposed to have been put forth by Christ or his apostles, and not committed to writing.
The act of delivering into the hands of another; delivery.

The unwritten or oral delivery of information, opinions, doctrines, practices, rites, and customs, from father to son, or from ancestors to posterity; the transmission of any knowledge, opinions, or practice, from forefathers to descendants by oral communication, without written memorials.
traditional: Observant of tradition; attached to old customs; old-fashioned.
traffic: Commerce, either by barter or by buying and selling; interchange of goods and commodities; trade.
The business done upon a railway, steamboat line, etc., with reference to the number of passengers or the amount of freight carried.
To pass goods and commodities from one person to another for an equivalent in goods or money; to buy or sell goods; to barter; to trade.
To trade meanly or mercenarily; to bargain.
trail: Anything drawn along, as a vehicle.
Anything drawn behind in long undulations; a train.
That part of the stock of a gun carriage which rests on the ground when the piece is unlimbered. See Illust. of Gun carriage, under Gun.
The act of taking advantage of the ignorance of a person; an imposition.
To be drawn out in length; to follow after.
To carry, as a firearm, with the breech near the ground and the upper part inclined forward, the piece being held by the right hand near the middle.
To draw or drag, as along the ground.
To grow to great length, especially when slender and creeping upon the ground, as a plant; to run or climb.
To hunt by the track; to track.
To take advantage of the ignorance of; to impose upon.
To tread down, as grass, by walking through it; to lay flat.
train: A connected line of cars or carriages on a railroad.
A consecution or succession of connected things; a series.
A heavy, long sleigh used in Canada for the transportation of merchandise, wood, and the like.
A line of gunpowder laid to lead fire to a charge, mine, or the like.
A number of followers; a body of attendants; a retinue; a suite.
Hence, something tied to a lure to entice a hawk; also, a trap for an animal; a snare.
That part of a gown which trails behind the wearer.
That which draws along; especially, persuasion, artifice, or enticement; allurement.
That which is drawn along in the rear of, or after, something; that which is in the hinder part or rear.
The after part of a gun carriage; the trail.
The number of beats of a watch in any certain time.
To be drilled in military exercises; to do duty in a military company.
To break, tame, and accustom to draw, as oxen.
To draw along; to trail; to drag.
To draw by persuasion, artifice, or the like; to attract by stratagem; to entice; to allure.
To trace, as a lode or any mineral appearance, to its head.
training: The act of one who trains; the act or process of exercising, disciplining, etc.; education.
transfer: A drawing or writing printed off from one surface on another, as in ceramics and in many decorative arts.
A pathological process by virtue of which a unilateral morbid condition on being abolished on one side of the body makes its appearance in the corresponding region upon the other side.
A picture, or the like, removed from one body or ground to another, as from wood to canvas, or from one piece of canvas to another.
A soldier removed from one troop, or body of troops, and placed in another.
The conveyance of right, title, or property, either real or personal, from one person to another, whether by sale, by gift, or otherwise.
transport: To carry, or cause to be carried, into banishment, as a criminal; to banish.
transportation: The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; carriage from one place to another; removal; conveyance.
travel: To pass; to go; to move.
treaty: A proposal tending to an agreement.
The act of treating for the adjustment of differences, as for forming an agreement; negotiation.
tree: Any perennial woody plant of considerable size (usually over twenty feet high) and growing with a single trunk.
trial: Any effort or exertion of strength for the purpose of ascertaining what can be done or effected.
Examination by a test; experiment, as in chemistry, metallurgy, etc.
The act of testing by experience; proof; test.
The act of trying or testing in any manner.

The formal examination of the matter in issue in a cause before a competent tribunal; the mode of determining a question of fact in a court of law; the examination, in legal form, of the facts in issue in a cause pending before a competent tribunal, for the purpose of determining such issue.
The state of being tried or tempted; exposure to suffering that tests strength, patience, faith, or the like; affliction or temptation that exercises and proves the graces or virtues of men.
trophy: A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle, or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimes trophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
Anything taken from an enemy and preserved as a memorial of victory, as arms, flags, standards, etc.
The representation of such a memorial, as on a medal; esp. (Arch.), an ornament representing a group of arms and military weapons, offensive and defensive.
tropical: Rhetorically changed from its exact original sense; being of the nature of a trope; figurative; metaphorical.
trust: Assured anticipation; dependence upon something future or contingent, as if present or actual; hope; belief.
Assured resting of the mind on the integrity, veracity, justice, friendship, or other sound principle, of another person; confidence; reliance; reliance.
That upon which confidence is reposed; ground of reliance; hope.
The condition or obligation of one to whom anything is confided; responsible charge or office.
To be confident, as of something future; to hope.
To give credence to; to believe; to credit.
To hope confidently; to believe; -- usually with a phrase or infinitive clause as the object.
To sell or deliver anything in reliance upon a promise of payment; to give credit.
try: A screen, or sieve, for grain.
To essay; to attempt; to endeavor.
To experience; to have or gain knowledge of by experience.
To purify or refine, as metals; to melt out, and procure in a pure state, as oil, tallow, lard, etc.
To subject to severe trial; to put to the test; to cause suffering or trouble to.
turkey: An empire in the southeast of Europe and southwest of Asia.
turkish: The language spoken by Turks, esp. that of the people of Turkey.
turn: A circuitous walk, or a walk to and fro, ending where it began; a short walk; a stroll.
A court of record, held by the sheriff twice a year in every hundred within his county.
A pit sunk in some part of a drift.
A round of a rope or cord in order to secure it, as about a pin or a cleat.
Hence, to give form to; to shape; to mold; to put in proper condition; to adapt.
One of the successive portions of a course, or of a series of occurrences, reckoning from change to change; hence, a winding; a bend; a meander.
Successive course; opportunity enjoyed by alternation with another or with others, or in due order; due chance; alternate or incidental occasion; appropriate time.
To be nauseated; -- said of the stomach.
To become acid; to sour; -- said of milk, ale, etc.
To become giddy; -- said of the head or brain.
To become inclined in the other direction; -- said of scales.
To bring down the feet of a child in the womb, in order to facilitate delivery.
To change from a given use or office; to divert, as to another purpose or end; to transfer; to use or employ; to apply; to devote.
To change from ebb to flow, or from flow to ebb; -- said of the tide.
To invert a type of the same thickness, as temporary substitute for any sort which is exhausted.
To result or terminate; to come about; to eventuate; to issue.
twelve: One more that eleven; two and ten; twice six; a dozen.
type: A general form or structure common to a number of individuals; hence, the ideal representation of a species, genus, or other group, combining the essential characteristics; an animal or plant possessing or exemplifying the essential characteristics of a species, genus, or other group. Also, a group or division of animals having a certain typical or characteristic structure of body maintained within the group.
A raised letter, figure, accent, or other character, cast in metal or cut in wood, used in printing.
A simple compound, used as a mode or pattern to which other compounds are conveniently regarded as being related, and from which they may be actually or theoretically derived.
Form or character impressed; style; semblance.
Such letters or characters, in general, or the whole quantity of them used in printing, spoken of collectively; any number or mass of such letters or characters, however disposed.
That which possesses or exemplifies characteristic qualities; the representative.
The mark or impression of something; stamp; impressed sign; emblem.
The original object, or class of objects, scene, face, or conception, which becomes the subject of a copy; esp., the design on the face of a medal or a coin.
To furnish an expression or copy of; to represent; to typify.
under: Denoting relation to something that exceeds in rank or degree, in number, size, weight, age, or the like; in a relation of the less to the greater, of inferiority, or of falling short.
understanding: Specifically, the discursive faculty; the faculty of knowing by the medium or use of general conceptions or relations. In this sense it is contrasted with, and distinguished from, the reason.
The act of one who understands a thing, in any sense of the verb; knowledge; discernment; comprehension; interpretation; explanation.

The power to understand; the intellectual faculty; the intelligence; the rational powers collectively conceived an designated; the higher capacities of the intellect; the power to distinguish truth from falsehood, and to adapt means to ends.
union: A cask suspended on trunnions, in which fermentation is carried on.

A joint or other connection uniting parts of machinery, or the like, as the elastic pipe of a tender connecting it with the feed pipe of a locomotive engine; especially, a pipe fitting for connecting pipes, or pipes and fittings, in such a way as to facilitate disconnection.
A textile fabric composed of two or more materials, as cotton, silk, wool, etc., woven together.
Agreement and conjunction of mind, spirit, will, affections, or the like; harmony; concord.
The act of uniting or joining two or more things into one, or the state of being united or joined; junction; coalition; combination.
unique: A thing without a like; something unequaled or unparalleled.
Being without a like or equal; unmatched; unequaled; unparalleled; single in kind or excellence; sole.
unit: A gold coin of the reign of James I., of the value of twenty shillings.
A single thing, as a magnitude or number, regarded as an undivided whole.
Any determinate amount or quantity (as of length, time, heat, value) adopted as a standard of measurement for other amounts or quantities of the same kind.
universal: The whole; the general system of the universe; the universe.
university: An association, society, guild, or corporation, esp. one capable of having and acquiring property.
until: As far as; to the place or degree that; especially, up to the time that; till. See Till, conj.
To; unto; towards; -- used of material objects.
up: Aloft; on high; in a direction contrary to that of gravity; toward or in a higher place or position; above; -- the opposite of down.

From a lower to a higher position, literally or figuratively; as, from a recumbent or sitting position; from the mouth, toward the source, of a river; from a dependent or inferior condition; from concealment; from younger age; from a quiet state, or the like; -- used with verbs of motion expressed or implied.
upon: On; -- used in all the senses of that word, with which it is interchangeable.
us: The persons speaking, regarded as an object; ourselves; -- the objective case of we. See We.
use: A stab of iron welded to the side of a forging, as a shaft, near the end, and afterward drawn down, by hammering, so as to lengthen the forging.
Continued or repeated practice; customary employment; usage; custom; manner; habit.
The premium paid for the possession and employment of borrowed money; interest; usury.
To be accustomed to go; to frequent; to inhabit; to dwell; -- sometimes followed by of.
valley: The depression formed by the meeting of two slopes on a flat roof.
The place of meeting of two slopes of a roof, which have their plates running in different directions, and form on the plan a reentrant angle.
